urn:contentItem:6GN4-5F03-S5NX-F1J7-00000-00One thousand trucks of earth to extinguish the fire at the landfill of A Rúa (Ourense)2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisOne thousand trucks of earth to extinguish the fire at the landfill of A Rúa (Ourense)


Tragsa company personnel are working to extinguish the fire that has been burning since August 15 in the landfill of A Rúa(Ourense), where it is planned to dump about a thousand trucks of earth and is expected to complete the work within a maximum period of two weeks.


The works started on Monday and are progressing with a "quite good" performance, said this Tuesday to EFE the head of the Tragsa Group in the northwest area(Galicia, Cantabria and Asturias), Manuel Villarroel, who explained that they have started to prepare the perimeter land of the landfill.
The forest fire declared in the municipality of Larouco (Ourense) reached A Rúa and ignited on August 15 this waste dump, where remains of textile components for car seats are deposited.
After two weeks in which the Xunta defended that the solution corresponded to the City Council while the municipality claimed not to have technical or economic capacity to do so, finally it was the Diputación de Ourense which assumed the task through an emergency contracting to Tragsa.
In the landfill work this Tuesday a wheel loader, a tracked cooler and trucks that are providing the aggregate, to move towards the center of the landfill and smother the fire, Villarroel has detailed.
The deposit has a surface of about 14,000 square meters and Tragsa estimates that about fifty centimeters of earth on average will be necessary, so about 7,000 cubic meters of aggregates will have to be deposited, about a thousand trucks.
The earth comes from a nearby construction site and the possibility of taking it from a municipal property near the site is being considered, but it is still necessary to obtain the necessary permits.
If they are obtained, the process will be expedited, which Tragsa expects to execute in a maximum of two weeks, barring complications.
The Diputación 's order is around 90,000 euros, a price that could vary depending on the conditions that are found as the work progresses, Villarroel pointed out.
The fire has kept the residents of A Rúa on tenterhooks for weeks, who had to wear masks to protect themselves from the smoke blown by the wind from the deposit.
The critical point of air quality was on August 26, but in recent days"the parameters have dropped to normal", has assured EFEthe councilman of Culture of A Rúa, José Vicente Solarat, who has celebrated that the work of extinction "are at the pace that was expected.
"The air quality is favorable, regardless of the nuisance generated by the smell and smoke, which is the only thing that remains fortunately. We are moderately optimistic," he noted.
The councilman hopes that the rain will also help to speed up the extinguishing work.

urn:contentItem:6GCX-KS13-S8N3-N496-00000-00Wildfire smoke degrades air quality in North Dakota again2025-07-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisBPg. 002Wildfire smoke degrades air quality in North Dakota againBISMARCK TRIBUNE STAFF

Air quality in North Dakota reached unhealthy levels again Wednesday as smoke from Canadian wildfires once again blanketed the state.

It’s been an intermittent issue all summer, as fires rage north of the border. There have been nearly 3,600 fires there so far this year burning more than 15 million acres, according to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre. That’s a total area about one-third the size of North Dakota.

Many of the fires listed as “out of control” are in the North Dakota-neighboring provinces of Saskatchewan and Manitoba.

North Dakota’s Department of Environmental Quality cautioned residents about the conditions, which could linger in coming days, according to smoke pattern predictions. People — especially those with respiratory conditions — are encouraged to limit outdoors activities when air quality is poor.

Information on wildfires and air quality is on the DEQ website, at bit.ly/3OhrD7E. The federal Environmental Protection Agency’s map of fire and smoke conditions is at https://fire.airnow.gov/. The AirNow mobile phone app, and many other weather apps, also include air quality information. AirNow is a partnership of federal and state agencies including the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

August 24th, 2025 ( Al Jazeera English - Delivered by Newstex )

Spain suffered 'the most intense' heatwave on record this month, the State Meteorological Agency (AEMET) has said, as firefighters battled wildfires in the north and west of the country.

In a statement on Sunday, the agency said that provisional readings for the August 3-18 heatwave exceeded the last record, set in July 2022, and showed an average temperature 4.6 degrees Celsius (40.2 Fahrenheit) higher than the expected threshold.

AEMET noted that the most recent heatwave, which saw temperatures reach 43C (109 F), is part of an escalating pattern of warmer summers due to the climate crisis.

'That four of the five most intense heat waves have occurred since 2019 is no coincidence,' it said. 'Not every summer will always be warmer than the previous one, but the trend toward more extreme summers is clear. The keys: adaptation and mitigation of climate change.'

Since it began its records in 1975, AEMET has registered 77 heatwaves in Spain, with six of them going 4C (39.2F) or more above the average.

More than 1,100 deaths in Spain have been linked to this year's August heatwave, according to an estimate released on Tuesday by the Carlos III Health Institute. The heatwave has also exacerbated tinderbox conditions in Spain, fuelling wildfires that continue to ravage parts of the country.

Last week, the Spanish army deployed 3,400 troops and 50 aircraft to help firefighters, while the Czech Republic, Finland, France, Germany, the Netherlands and Slovakia also sent hundreds of firefighters, vehicles and aircraft.

The fires have burned more than 382,000 hectares (944,000 acres) or about 3,820 sq km (1,475 sq miles), according to the European Union's European Forest Fire Information System.

Most of Southern Europe is experiencing one of its worst wildfire seasons in two decades.

Europe has been warming twice as fast as the global average since the 1980s, according to the EU's Copernicus Climate Change Service.

Heatwaves and dry conditions, which scientists link to climate change, have become more frequent across the world in recent years.

The World Health Organization has warned, 'With climate change leading to warmer temperatures and drier conditions and the increasing urbanization of rural areas, the fire season is starting earlier and ending later.

'Wildfire events are getting more extreme in terms of acres burned, duration and intensity, and they can disrupt transportation, communications, water supply, and power and gas services.'

Link to the original story.

urn:contentItem:6GKD-DFT3-RRR5-S0RX-00000-00Recent heatwave in Spain was the most intense ever recorded2025-08-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisRecent heatwave in Spain was the most intense ever recorded


The 16-day heatwave that hit Spain in August was "the most intense since records began" in the country, the National Meteorological Agency (Aemet) reported on Sunday (24) on the X social network.


According to provisional data, it surpassed that of July 2022, with temperatures 4.6°C higher than the usual maximum for a heatwave.
In the record phenomenon of 2022, this temperature deviation was 4.5°C, according to Aemet.
According to the agency, 77 heatwaves have been recorded in Spain since 1975, six of which had an anomaly of 4°C or more. However, five of them have occurred since 2019, an indication of the worsening of these phenomena.
The heatwave lasted from August 3 to 18, and the period from August 8 to 17 "was the hottest set of ten consecutive days recorded in Spain since at least 1950," revealed Aemet.
According to estimates by the Carlos 3º Health Institute (ISCIII), more than 1,100 deaths can be attributed to this recent wave.
The exact figure is 1,149, according to the ISCIII's MoMo system, which studies variations in daily general mortality in relation to what would be expected according to historical series.
It then integrates the external factors that can explain this difference. These include, in particular, the temperatures reported by Aemet.
The system cannot establish an absolute causality between the deaths recorded and the weather conditions, but the figures constitute the best estimate of the balance of deaths in which the heatwave may have been the decisive factor.
In July, MoMo had attributed around 1,060 deaths to the heat, which represented an increase of more than 50% compared to the same period in 2024.
In addition, the heat has fueled the large forest fires still active in Spain and Portugal, with eight deaths, four in each country, which have devastated more than 400,000 hectares between the two states.
With the end of the high temperatures, the weather conditions have begun to favor the work of the firefighters, who have the support of soldiers from Spain and other countries. Even so, authorities warned that it would take weeks for the outbreaks to be completely extinguished.
According to data from the European Copernicus satellite, since the beginning of the year around 373,000 hectares have been burnt in Spain, a steadily rising figure that already represents an annual record for the country since the European Forest Fire Information System (Effis) began collecting this information in 2006.

urn:contentItem:6GM8-B743-RV53-B46P-00000-00Alberta deficit climbs a to $6.5B in first-quarter update2025-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisFRONTPg. A1Alberta deficit climbs a to $6.5B in first-quarter updateKevin Sabo

Finance Minister Nate Horner’s February budget pegged the deficit at $5.2 billion, but the first-quarter update now puts the shortfall at $6.5 billion.

Total revenue is forecast at about $73 billion, against $79 billion in expenses.

“We know the road ahead has its challenges, but with disciplined financial management and smart investments, we will stand by families, rein in the deficit and secure a stronger future,” said Horner, in a press release along with the update. “Careful fiscal management matters.”

According to the update, the biggest factor influencing the province’s budget is a 38 per cent drop in natural resource prices, which has resulted in a forecast revenue of $15.7 billion in 2025-26, down from $25.2 billion.

The price per barrel in 2025-26 is forecast at $63 USD, down from $89 in 2022.

Other factors influencing the province’s budget include a growing population, anticipated to increase by 2.4 per cent over the next year, tariff threats, and slowing global growth.

“Even with these challenges, Alberta remains committed to prioritizing essential services such as health care and education, while keeping everyday costs like childcare, utilities and housing affordable for families,” notes the release.

Included in Budget 2025-26 was a $4 billion contingency fund, of which $2.5 billion remains. Of the $1.5 billion allocated, over $700 million has been spent on disaster and emergency relief, $700 million on wildfire response, and $6 million on re-planting trees in forest fire-affected areas.

“Despite external shocks, Alberta’s economy remains resilient. Its real GDP is forecast to lead Canada, and the private sector continues to perform strongly with investment, construction and labour market activity supporting stability,” notes the release.

Alberta NDP Shadow Minister for Finance Court Ellingson said the latest update is disappointing.

“Nearly half of Albertans are staring down the barrel of financial insolvency. Grocery prices are climbing higher than people can keep up with. Auto insurance rates are growing out of control. Rents are skyrocketing. Unemployment is climbing. The only thing that appears to be falling are real wages in this province,” he said.

“This government can’t even claim fiscal responsibility as an excuse for the pain they’re causing. Despite all the cuts, they’ve still managed to drive the province into deficit. That means Albertans are paying more, getting less, and still being left with a government that can’t balance the books.”

Alberta’s operating expense is forecast at seeee $65 billion, $679 million more than budgeted, primarily due to public-sector wage growth.

The province is not alone in its budget woes; Saskatchewan is predicting a $349 million deficit after predicting a $12 million surplus, and New Brunswick’s deficit continues to climb, rising from $549 million to $668.7 million.

urn:contentItem:6GKV-9VM3-RXRP-04M5-00000-00Tapir rescued in Teodoro with burns on 70% of its body loses sight and will not be able to return to the wild2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisTapir rescued in Teodoro with burns on 70% of its body loses sight and will not be able to return to the wild


The first case officially reported by a center accredited by the state government of a wild animal victim of a forest fire was recorded last weekend. It was an adult female tapir, rescued on Friday night, the 21st, in Teodoro Sampaio. The animal is under intensive care at Apass (Wild Animal Protection Association) in Assis. The information was released by Semil (Secretariat for the Environment, Infrastructure and Logistics) on Tuesday.


According to the organization, the tapir has 1st, 2nd and 3rd degree burns on around 70% of its body, total loss of sight and a compromised ear. Despite the severity, she is eating and drinking water voluntarily. "We're working hard to ensure comfort and quality of life for this animal, even though we know it won't be possible to return it to the wild. This is a patient who will require prolonged care, with protocols for analgesia, antibiotics and anti-inflammatories and management of the injuries. The support we received from partner organizations was fundamental in making this rescue happen," explains Apass' executive director, Natália Tomaz Inácio de Godoy.
As reported in this newspaper, the rescue was carried out by brigade members from Morro do Diabo State Park, together with the Environmental Military Police and several volunteers. The tapir was found weakened, with serious injuries, inside a dam in the middle of a sugarcane field. To transport it to Assis, about 180 kilometers from the site, the DER (Department of Highways) provided a truck and driver, ensuring the animal's safe arrival at Apass on the night of August 22.
It is suspected that the injuries are the result of a fire that occurred on August 17, in the Morro do Diabo State Park region - the only event recorded this month. As a result, the tapir remained injured for at least five days, without care, until it reached the reservoir. The case draws attention to the impact of fires on wildlife and the importance of integration between environmental agencies, partner organizations and civil society.
"This incident highlights the importance of the joint efforts of the Forestry Foundation and the Environmental Military Police to save lives, as well as the essential role of accredited institutions, such as Apass, in the reception and treatment of rescued animals. It also reinforces the importance of all the enterprises that make up the network of Cetras [Wild Animal Screening and Rehabilitation Centers] keeping their notifications up to date on the state government's platform. This control is fundamental for monitoring and responding efficiently to critical events that threaten São Paulo's biodiversity," said Liliane Milanelo, Semil's Cetras Management coordinator.

urn:contentItem:6GPD-FF03-RWY5-Y50T-00000-00Southwestern Europe scorched by extreme heat during world's third-warmest August on record2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisSouthwestern Europe scorched by extreme heat during world's third-warmest August on record

August brought southwest Europe's third major heatwave of the summer, accompanied by exceptional wildfires.

This August was the world's third-warmest August on record, according to the EU's Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S).

Temperatures were 0.49°C above the 1991 to 2020 average for the month. C3S data shows that August 2025 was 0.22°C cooler than the two warmest Augusts on record in 2023 and 2024.

Compared to the pre-industrial level, last month was 1.29°C warmer. And C3S says the last 12 months, from September 2024 to August 2025, have been 0.64°C above the 1991 to 2020 average and 1.53°C above the pre-industrial level.

Overall, this summer has been the world's third warmest on record, at 0.47°C above the 1991 to 2020 average. It was only cooler than the summers of 2023 and 2024.

August brings the southwest Europe's third major heatwave

At an average of 19.46°C, August in Europe was 0.3°C above average this year. This puts it outside of the continent's 10 warmest Augusts in Copernicus's data records.

But there were still some hotspots. The Iberian Peninsula and southwest France were particularly affected by heatwave conditions.

Related

Summer 2025 was UK's hottest on record and experts say 'extremes' like this are becoming more common

Climate change fuelled wildfires of 'unprecedented intensity' in Spain and Portugal, experts say

“In southwest Europe, the month brought the third major heatwave of the summer, accompanied by exceptional wildfires," said Samantha Burgess, Strategic Lead for Climate at European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF).

(Left) Average daily maximum surface air temperature during 11 days from 8 to 18 August 2025. (Right) Average daily mean surface air temp anomalies during the same period. C3S/ECMWF Data source: ERA5

More than a million hectares of land have gone up in flames across Europe so far this year, an area larger than Cyprus.

In Spain, almost 400,000 hectares of land have burned since January, according to the Copernicus European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS). More than 260,000 hectares have burned in Portugal.

A rapid analysis by World Weather Attribution found that hot, dry and windy conditions, which fuelled these fires, were made more likely and more intense by climate change.

Overall, Europe has seen its fourth warmest summer season on record at 0.9°C above the 1991 to 2020 average. Summer temperatures were above average across almost all of the continent. The only exception was some parts of Eastern Europe.

The season also brought drier-than-average conditions in much of the western and southern parts of the continent, as well as in the Balkans and Black Sea regions, and in parts of Scandinavia, Finland and northwestern Russia.

The world's oceans are unusually warm

The average sea surface temperature (SST) across most of the world's oceans was 20.82°C - the third highest value on record.

Most of the North Pacific saw much above-average SSTs, with record highs reached in some areas.

"With the world’s ocean also remaining unusually warm, these events underline not only the urgency of reducing emissions but also the critical need to adapt to more frequent and intense climate extremes," Burgess said.

Related

New marine survey reveals fragile ecosystems off Cyprus under threat from human activity

Even moderate warming could cause irreversible damage to Mediterranean ecosystems, experts warn

In Europe, August was a more mixed picture. While sea surface temperatures were much less extreme than in 2024 across the Mediterranean, record highs continued in August across an area of the North Atlantic to the west of France and the UK.

urn:contentItem:6GKV-9WM3-RY9B-V2K3-00000-00Alarm in Galicia over a large landfill that nobody puts out after the fires: "We don't know what we are breathing".2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisAlarm in Galicia over a large landfill that nobody puts out after the fires: "We don't know what we are breathing".


The forest fires that have devastated the region of Valdeorras, in Ourense, have left in the municipality of A Rúa a smoldering mass of plastic and textile waste. It is a huge landfill of the remains of anti-thermal carpets used in the manufacture of automobiles. These insulating covers are designed to burn very slowly. To the distress of the more than 4,000 inhabitants of this municipality, this slow combustion has been going on since last August 15, when the flames of the Larouco fire, the most serious of this wave in Galicia, entered this municipal deposit.


Twelve days have passed and this waste, classified as non-hazardous, continues to burn without any administration having taken charge of its complicated sealing for the time being. "We are totally unprotected. It is very unpleasant and we don't know what we are breathing," protests an employee of one of the companies in the As Pedreiras industrial estate next to where the site is located. Many of them go to work with masks and goggles to face an increasingly unbreathable environment, they say. The landfill is about 300 meters from the business park, 400 meters from homes and barely a kilometer from two schools that will start classes on September 8.
All the technicians who have visited the landfill these days, both from public institutions and private companies, estimate that it will take more than a month of work "at a good pace" to seal the 14,000 cubic meters of waste and bury their bad fumes, explains the mayor of A Rúa, María González Albert, of the BNG. It will require 1,200 trucks full of sand and operators protected with special suits with their corresponding security plan, a deployment that the City Council says it cannot finance.
The PP's Xunta washes its hands of the matter. The Consellería de Medio Ambiente alleges that the deposit, which occupies more than 16,000 square meters, is municipal property and that it should be the City Council who should quell the fire and close the landfill if it opts for this alternative. "It is a municipal facility, yes, but if it burned [by a forest fire] the town hall, wouldn't the firefighters come?", asks the councilwoman about the inaction of the Galician Government, which has the powers to extinguish forest fires.
If the Executive of Alfonso Rueda considers that the fire in the landfill is urban, adds the mayor, suffocate it would be the responsibility of the Diputación de Ourense, also governed by the popular. This institution has sent staff to the site to assess the problem, but on Tuesday, to questions from this newspaper, has avoided involvement in the solution: "That issue is being managed directly by the City Council of A Rúa with the Xunta". The nationalist alderwoman cries out against this "frustrating" neglect: "They pass the buck to each other. They are letting the weather run to rain or stop combustion and get rid of the problem".
The Xunta station that measures the air quality in this municipality qualifies it as "very bad" with the data collected this Tuesday at noon. The records have been worsening mainly due to the high presence of "pollutants PM25 and PM10", according to the report of the regional agency Meteogalicia. The mayor of A Rúa explains that this foul environment has to do not only with the fumes from these wastes, but also with the forest fire that is still active in the area.
The Xunta considers that these data collected by the mobile unit displaced there "motivate that, for the moment, the alert phase is maintained". This level implies a "constant vigilance" and the communication of the measurements to the City Council and the regional teams of emergencies and public health to disseminate "recommendations" to the population.
The neighbors are worried. Workers of the industrial estate explain that the quality of the air they breathe is worse than that reflected in the records of the Xunta because the unit that performs the measurements has been located in the municipal pavilion, a couple of kilometers from the landfill. They also claim that it smells "like burnt tires" and fear that more than just insulating material has been deposited on the site. The councilwoman denies it: "No, there are only carpets, that is super-controlled".
Toxicity spreads to other municipalities
The landfill has been municipal since 2010, but for years it has been accumulating waste from a single factory, that of Autoneum. This factory, located in the same industrial park and where 190 people worked, was destroyed by the Larouco fire. The depot is one kilometer away from a high school and a school and the parents' associations of these centers are mobilizing to demand measures for the start of the school year.
The deputy mayor of A Rúa, the socialist Ana Fernández, has also demanded "help" from the Xunta to extinguish the fire at the dump because, in her opinion, it has become a public health problem. She wields that the economic resources of such a small town council are "very far" from reaching to finance the complex operation that requires the sealing of the deposit affected by the wave of forest fires.
The plastic and textile waste it contains, warns Fernandez, will continue to "contaminate the municipality of A Rúa and the surrounding areas while they do not put the resources on the table" to extinguish its slow combustion. The leader of his party, José Ramón Gómez Besteiro, who visited the deposit this Monday, assures that the consequences of this "toxic" fire have already spread to the neighboring town of Petín: "What is happening in A Rúa is the proof of how Rueda governs: absent when there are problems".
Both BNG and PSOE urge the appearance of the president of the Xunta in the Galician Parliament to explain the management of a crisis in which there have been complaints of lack of coordination and stopped means by members of the extinction device. The parliamentary spokesman of the Galician PP, Alberto Pazos, said Tuesday that Rueda "will not hide" and will give "all the explanations" about the performance of his government. The unions CCOO, CSIF and UGT, meanwhile, demand dismissals and relays in the Department of Rural Environment for a management that they describe as "nefarious" and "negligent".

urn:contentItem:6F07-8V43-S6XH-8000-00000-00Acrobatics "Wind, Forest, Fire and the Mountain"2025-01-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisAcrobatics "Wind, Forest, Fire and the Mountain"JINAN, China, Jan. 26, 2025

PR NewswireJINAN, China, Jan. 26, 2025 /PRNewswire/ --Areport from Shandian News.On January 27th, 2024 Shandong Spring Festival Gala will be broadcast.Acrobatics "Wind, Forest, Fire and the Mountain"showcases the marching principles inThe Art of Warby Sun Tzuthrough acrobatic moves: "As fast as the wind, as quiet as the forest, as aggressive as the fire, as firm as the mountain". The Art of Warby Sun Tzuis an important representative of ancient Chinese thought and an essential part of traditional Chinese culture. In 1972, precious bamboo slips featuring military classics such asThe Art of War by Sun TzuandSun Bin's Art of Warwere unearthed from the two Yinqueshan Han Tombs in Linyi City, Shandong Province.In the display of the acrobatic skill of "tumbling on the pole", the poles are like the bamboo slips, while the acrobats act as the characters on these slips. Virtual technology and subjective shooting are employed to enrich the performance, allowing the audience to fully appreciate the profound thinking of ancient Chinese military strategists during the pre-Qin period and see through the inheritance and evolution of ancient Chinese military culture throughout the history.

urn:contentItem:6H09-6N03-RRV9-Y003-00000-00Rokmaster channel samples 14.6% Zn+Pb over 4.5 m on Duncan Lake Project and Receives Drill Permits on Duncan Lake and Big Copper Projects2025-10-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisRokmaster channel samples 14.6% Zn+Pb over 4.5 m on Duncan Lake Project and Receives Drill Permits on Duncan Lake and Big Copper ProjectsVANCOUVER, BC, Oct. 16, 2025

PR NewswireVANCOUVER, BC, Oct. 16, 2025 /PRNewswire/ - Rokmaster Resources Corp. (TSXV: RKR) (OTCQB: RKMSF) (FSE: 1RR1) ("Rokmaster" or "the Company") is pleased to provide an update for the Duncan Lake and Big Copper Projects.Both the Duncan Lake Project and Big Copper Project are located in southeastern British Columbia and have been steadily advanced by Rokmaster since 2018. Both Projects feature road access in favourable regions with the Trail Smelter within 170 km of the Duncan Lake Project and with the mining town of Kimberley, BC around the Sullivan Deposit within 50 km of the Big Copper Project (Figure 1).A five-year Multi-year Area Based Exploration Permit ("MYAB Permit") was recently approved on theDuncan Lake Projectby the British Columbia Ministry of Mining and Critical Minerals (Figure 2). The MYAB Permit allows for up to 21 drill sites north of the historic Duncan Mine, which was developed by Cominco 1957-1960. Cominco identified eight mineralized zones but never produced ore from the mine. Between 1989 and 1997, Cominco and Teck Resources completed 12 diamond drillholes approximately 2,000 metres north of the Duncan Mine which intersected strong lead-zinc mineralization in the east limb of the north plunging Duncan Anticline.

Rokmaster completed a small drill program in 2022 by re-entering one of these historic drillholes, which are all now on Rokmaster claims, and successfully intersected the west limb of the Duncan Anticline and cored a wide interval of Zn-Pb-Ag mineralization in the east limb (see news release dated May 17, 2022). There is also a five year MYAB Permit covering the southern No.3, No.2, and No.1 Zones previously approved on the Duncan Lake Project. These zones were partially defined in the 1960's by Cominco who completed small trenching programs on surface exposures of massive sphalerite-galena mineralization in the east limb of the Duncan Anticline. This MYAB Permit allows for 26 drillsites and 15 trenches and while it expired in August 2025, an application to extend the end date on the permit due to a large forest fire which burned the region in 2024. The fire extensively burned throughout the No.2 Zone, No.1 Zone, and the Mag Zone with good potential for new outcrop exposure. The application to extend the permit was submitted in April 2025 and is currently in the consultation stage since June 2025.Field work on the Duncan Lake Project in 2025 included trenching at the No.3 Zone and further prospecting and sampling in the Mag Zone (Figure 3). This work followed 2023 sampling which collected 127 soil samples and 22 rock samples1. Three of the trenches completed at the No.3 Zone returned high lead and zinc results with appreciable silver grades over meter-scale widths with channel sampling. An outcrop exposure at the No.1 Zone, approximately 3.1 km south of the No.3 Zone, was also channel sampled returning 14.64% combined lead and zinc with 6.67 g/t Ag over 4.5 m (Table 1). More advanced geochemical analysis is ongoing to assess the germanium, gallium, and indium concentrations in the mineralization.Table1: Duncan Lake Project Trench Sample Assay Results No. 3 and No.1 ZonesNotes to Table 1:
1. Widths reported are sampled widths, such that true thicknesses are unknown.
2. All assay intervals represent length-weighted averages.
3. Some figures may not sum exactly due to rounding.
4. Samples were prepared and analyzed by MSALABS in Langley BC. After preparation, samples were analyzed for 30 elements including Zn, Pb and Ag by 4-acid digestion of a 0.2 g subsample with ICP-ES finish (MSALAB ore-grade method ICP-240).A five year MYAB Permit was recently approved on theBig Copper Projectby the British Columbia Ministry of Mining and Critical Minerals (Figure 4). The MYAB Permit allows for 20 helicopter-supported drillsites and 4 helicopter pads. A field work program was completed on the Big Copper Project in 2023 which collected 165 soil samples and 11 rock samples, highlighting anomalous silver values in the southern portion of the Property2. The Big Copper Property hosts a mineralized deformation and alteration front approximately 4.5 km in strike defined by at least three adits, outcrops, seven trenches and several drillholes which support strong copper-silver mineralization. Mineralized zones are hosted within fine-grained siltstones, argillites and dirty quartzites of the Creston formation. The Creston formation is correlative with the Revett Formation which hosts several large sedimentary hosted copper-silver deposits and undeveloped occurrences in northern Montana and Idaho, including the Spar Lake, Montanore and Rock Creek deposits. John Mirko, President and CEO, comments:"Having these exploration drill permits in hand provides Rokmaster the flexibility to get right to work on these fantastic projects. We have held and advanced the Duncan Lake and Big Copper Projects for many years and believe in the high potential for exploration success on both. Zinc and copper are critical elements which are very important in the current environment, and both projects have an ideal address for a discovery to be made and developed. The elevated silver concentrations on both projects, particularly on the Duncan Lake Project where the strength and significance of silver may not have been fully recognized, is what we're excited to test in addition to the increasingly critical elements."Financing UpdateThe Company is also pleased to announce that further to its news release on October 7, 2025 that it has closed the first tranche of the flow-through funding (the "FT Financing") with the issuance of 11,450,000 FT Units (the "FT Units") at a price of $0.04 per FT Unit for gross proceeds of $458,000 (the "First Tranche").Each FT Unit issued in the First Tranche is comprised of one flow-through common share (the "FT Share") plus one-half (1/2) non-transferable non-flow-through share purchase warrant (each whole warrant, a "NFT Warrant"). Each NFT Warrant is exercisable to purchase one additional non-flow-through common share of the Company (the "NFT Warrant Share") at $0.06 for a period of two years expiring on October 15, 2027.The FT Shares will qualify as "flow-through shares" (within the meaning of subsection 66(15) of theIncome Tax Act(Canada) (the "Tax Act"). The gross proceeds raised from the issuance of the FT Shares will be used by the Company to incur "Canadian exploration expenses" (within the meaning of the Tax Act).In connection with the First Tranche, the Company paid cash finder's fees of $14,000 and issued 350,000 finder's warrants (the "Finder's Warrant") with respect to the sale of FT Units to an arm's length subscriber. Each Finder's Warrant entitles the holder to purchase one additional common share of the Company at $0.05 for a period of two years expiring on October 15, 2027.The securities issued pursuant to the First Tranche and Finder's Warrants are subject to a four-month and one day hold period expiring on February 16, 2026.Footnote #1: 2023 Geochemical Assessment Report Duncan Lake Project. British Columbia Assessment Report Database Report #42000Footnote #2: 2023 Assessment Report Big Copper Property. urn:contentItem:6GKF-M0M3-RRY6-5046-00000-00Ignore the igneous, by Redacción2025-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisIgnore the igneous, by Redacción


Antoni Trasobares and Míriam Piqué belong to the Center of Forest Science and Technology of Catalonia and to the European Project FIRE-RES // César Dopazo and Ignacio Romagosa are members of the Royal Academy of Engineering.
This note could be subtitled "from that inaction come these fires" or, the so hackneyed, "summer fires are extinguished in winter". Compared to the summers of 2023 and 2024, the summer of 2025 is being extremely virulent with a tragic balance of human lives, threat to populations and properties, and destructive impact on an important extension of the natural environment. It is inexcusable to analyze existing legislation, rules and regulations on forest fires in order to update them without complexes and with realism in the face of the current climatological reality, which, foreseeably, will be more extreme in the future.


Strategically planning prevention, land use, forest management and early warning and extinction tasks is a mission that both the State and regional governments can no longer avoid and for which they must rely on real experts in each of the above-mentioned areas.
In the face of this national emergency, it is necessary to leave behind the politics of mutual partisan accusations and return to level politics, addressing the root of the problem and proposing applied solutions.
It is essential to resort to scientific knowledge in different disciplines related to forests and the combustion of vegetation masses to lessen the destructive effects of the so-called "sixth generation" fires that pessimists consider uncontrollable, especially when they myopically think only of the increase of modestly paid human resources. The global climatic emergency, the abandonment of the rural and forest environment and the poor planning of our landscape put us at risk, because the legal limitations and the available means make it impossible to manage our territories as it would be necessary.
The initiation and spread of a fire depends crucially on the available fuel, an ignition source, the physical variables of the atmosphere and topography.
The reduction of available fuel requires a rigorous and planned management of the territory, together with a sustainable use and valorization of agroforestry products resulting from this management (wood for construction, biomass for energy generation, among others). The adaptation of urban developments requires the management of the urban-forest interface, creating and maintaining areas of low fuel load and promoting self-protection measures.
Legislation applicable to arsonists and arsonists must be tightened as much as possible, along with the installation of means of surveillance, cleaning and maintenance of facilities that can act as combustion initiators and early warning systems.
Forest management that minimizes the most easily combustible biomass would significantly reduce heat generation and, consequently, the strong interaction of combustion with atmospheric physical variables (wind speed, temperature, humidity, turbulence structure, etc.), reported in "sixth generation" (non-extinguishable?) fires and observable in the formation of pyrocumulus.
The definition of priority management zones and efficient ad hoc fire breaks can counteract the effect of topography on fire spread. Previous numerical simulations of spread with different amounts of fuel, different atmospheric and topographic variables, combined with artificial intelligence techniques and monitoring and measurement systems, will be a valuable guide in the definition of extinguishing strategies.
"Sooner rather than later, we may suffer major forest fires in Spain" was the premonitory statement in the conclusions of the seminar Forest Fires in Spain which, in October 2024, organized by the Royal Academy of Engineering and the Center for Forest Science and Technology of Catalonia, brought together in Madrid experts in fire prevention, management of the rural environment and mathematical simulation of their spread. The consensus was general: neither firefighting teams nor forest fire experts can plan strategies to deal with this threat without decisive political action.
The equation is simple: climate change has led us to new scenarios that we are able to foresee, but extreme fires are a reality that generates its own conditions to advance unchecked. Today, not only their control but also the prediction and simulation of these fires is a challenge that is still unapproachable.
Global and integrative thinking is needed. Prevention must necessarily involve the enhancement of forest resources and the implementation of management formulas that make it possible to generate new conditions and, at the same time, maintain the population in rural areas. The abandonment of agricultural land, which in the last 30 years has caused the biomass present in forests to double, must be reversed.
The forest invades space if we do not contain or guide it. For example, in Catalonia, the forest occupies around 15% more area than it did three decades ago. It is essential to recover the mosaic of uses that the rural environment had before this abandonment. We need to redraw, with scientific criteria, a large part of our territory and establish what should be forest and how it should be managed, what should be fields and how we protect the populations.
In Spain, there is scientific knowledge of the highest level as a basis for endorsing profound territorial and social changes that make nature the main ally in the fight against climate change, drought and biodiversity conservation, while activating a new bioeconomy of the future.
We propose an Applied Forest Fire Research Program to lead this challenge and prepare the territory for potential large fires. A program that could be linked to the 2023 declaration of the Pau Costa Foundation, to allocate at least 1 billion euros per year to this mission.
The challenge is monumental. We are seeing the consequences of the fires in Korea and California, and those ravaging the Iberian Peninsula and Southeast Europe (Greece, Montenegro, Bulgaria) this summer 2025. They are becoming more frequent and destructive. Climate change is not going to stop, but its effects can be mitigated using scientific knowledge as a guide. Politicians and social agents have to design a comprehensive and consensual strategy, because the next generations deserve it.

urn:contentItem:6FC9-BSC3-S8XX-746C-00000-00Assam: Massive Forest Fire Engulfs Manderdisa In Dima Hasao, 10 Bighas Affected2025-03-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisAssam: Massive Forest Fire Engulfs Manderdisa In Dima Hasao, 10 Bighas AffectedSentinel Digital Desk

HAFLONG: In a tragic incident, a massive forest fire erupted yesterday in Manderdisa located in the Dima Hasao district of Assam. The fire rapidly spread across the Sengyungpur village forest, as per reports.

However, four fire engines from Lumding and Hojai Sankardev Nagar arrived at the scene and successfully brought the fire under control. Reports claim that the blaze affected approximately 10 bighas of forest area.

The entire village was reportedly saved because of the prompt response from the Lumding Fire Department. As the investigation is underway, the exact cause of the fire is yet to be determined.

In another similar incident, a massive fire broke out at Harengajao Market in Assam's Dima Hasao district at around 3 AM earlier on March 9, destroying over 100 shops and houses.

Fire brigades from Harengajao, Haflong, and Cachar worked together to control the blaze. The damage is estimated at over Rs 1 crore. Authorities have launched an investigation into the cause of the fire.

Meanwhile, a devastating fire broke out in the early hours of February 12 in Lumding's Harulongpar area in Assam's Hojai district, gutting four railway quarters and four commercial establishments at Charge Road, Last Colony. The fire, which is suspected to have originated from a business establishment, was noticed by locals at around 4:30 AM.

urn:contentItem:6GKF-M0M3-RRY6-504C-00000-00The evolution of the fires: de-escalation and resettlement in Extremadura and Zamora2025-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisThe evolution of the fires: de-escalation and resettlement in Extremadura and Zamora


The situation of the forest fires has improved in the last hours and has allowed the relocation of residents of villages affected by the fires of Porto (Zamora) and Jarilla (Cáceres), where the danger has also de-escalated, as in Molezuelas (Zamora).


In spite of this, the favorable evolution in the fight against the fire has been overshadowed by the death of a man who participated as a volunteer in the extinction of the fire in Cipérez (Salamanca) and died days after being hospitalized, although the Junta de Castilla y León has denied the link between the death and smoke inhalation from the fire.
A total of 41 people arrested in connection with the forest fires
Three injured brigadistas and a firefighter are still in hospital in A Coruña, one of them with a very serious prognosis and another is progressing favorably.
So far, the wave of fires raging in Spain has devastated more than 400,000 hectares, the largest area burned so far this century and the largest recorded since 1994, according to the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).
Since the beginning of June, law enforcement agencies have arrested a total of 41 people for forest fires and are investigating a further 127.
In the last hours, it has been known that the Guardia Civil is investigating two men, a 37 year old Portuguese man and a 30 year old resident of Monterroso, as alleged perpetrators of two crimes of forest fire by serious negligence in this town and in Folgoso do Courel (Lugo).
The Civil Guard is also investigating a 59-year-old farmer as the alleged perpetrator of the fire on July 31 in the Foncabada area, belonging to the municipality of Villamol (Leon).
According to the DGT, because of the fire there are six roads of the secondary network cut off in Castilla y León and another one in Extremadura.
Extremadura breathes a sigh of relief
The Jarilla fire, the largest in the recent history of Extremadura, which has affected about 17,300 hectares, has been stabilized after eleven active days, and therefore has been de-escalated from level two to one, so that the operation is now controlled with the means and resources of the autonomous community.
The residents of the houses in the periurban area of Hervás are already returning to their homes, as well as those of isolated houses in Jerte, Tornavacas, Cabezuela and Navaconcejo.
However, work is being maintained in the area because there are some hot spots in the northwest of the fire.
Relocation of populations in Porto (Zamora)
The situation in the province of Zamora has improved this Friday. On the one hand, five populations evacuated by the fire in Porto de Sanabria have been relocated and, on the other hand, the severity of the fire in Molezuelas de la Carballeda has been reduced to zero, after being active since August 10.
That fire, which the Junta de Castilla y León considers intentional and in which two people died in the province of León, is the most serious in burned area of the year and one of the largest since there are records.
Finally, this Friday have returned to their homes the residents of five towns that had been evacuated last Monday by the fire in Porto, and only Ribadelago Viejo and Ribadelago Nuevo remain evacuated.
The fire maintains the same perimeter, more than 100 kilometers, without hardly advancing the last two days, and only flame is seen on the border between Zamora and Leon of the Sierra de la Cabrera, and columns of smoke in the canyon of Tera.
However, the village of Argayo del Sil, belonging to the León municipality of Páramo del Sil, has had to be evacuated due to the proximity of the Anllares fire, which is advancing rapidly.
The fires of Yeres (which devastated Las Médulas) and Paradiña, both in the Leonese region of El Bierzo, have reduced their danger level to 0 - on a scale of 0 to 2 -.
In total, eight serious fires are still active in Castilla y León, in the provinces of Zamora, Palencia and León.
The emergency in Carballedo (Lugo) is deactivated.
Eight fires are active this Friday in Galicia, five of them in Ourense, which have devastated more than 78,000 hectares, and three other outbreaks that were declared on Thursday in the provinces of Pontevedra and Lugo, where there have been evictions.
In addition, the emergency has been deactivated by the fire affecting the municipality of Carballedo (Lugo), declared on Thursday because of its proximity to the town of Oleiros, but are preventively evicted 53 children and eleven monitors of the Albergue dos Peares.
In Asturias: three fires active and two stabilized
Compared to the almost twenty fires that in recent days came to register simultaneously in Asturias, early Saturday morning had been reduced to five, of which three remain active and two stabilized.
The Degaña fire is the most worrying and concentrates more means of extinction to maintain the three lines of action on which they are working to control the fire: one in the border area between Asturias and León, another in Trascastro, within the municipality of Peranzanes, and a third in the port of Cienfuegos.
The fire in Genestoso (Cangas del Narcea) and Somiedo came from the Leonese outbreak in Orallo, with the intervention of Asturian firefighters, Greek firefighters, forestry companies and a helicopter from Navarra. In Somiedo (Caunedo-Gúa-Perlunes), work is concentrated on the outbreaks "above Caunedo", with support from Asturias and Andorra firefighters, forestry crews and a regional helicopter.
The stabilized fires are the one in La Uña/Arcenorio (Ponga) and the one in Cabrales (Camarmeña), which remains under surveillance by the Natural Environment Guard.
The weather forecast indicates that from now on the weather conditions will improve, which could favor the extinction of the fire.

urn:contentItem:6GJS-XXV3-RRVX-P09X-00000-00Spain's wildfires almost vanquished, official says2025-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisSpain's wildfires almost vanquished, official says

(Alliance News) - Spain has almost beaten back wildfires that have swept across the country this month, killing four people and ravaging huge swathes of land, the head of its civil protection and emergencies service said Saturday.

"There are fewer of them, and the end is a lot nearer," the official, Virginia Barcones, told state television network TVE.

The ones remaining were still very "treacherous", she said, however, and "we will need a final push to be done with this horrible situation".

Spanish firefighters, helped by other EU countries, have been battling blazes that have scorched a record 403,000 hectares, 996,000 acres, most of it in the past two weeks, according to the European Forest Fire Information System.

The regions hardest hit were in the north and the west: Castile & Leon, Extremadura, and Galicia. The wildfires flared during a heatwave that baked the country for two weeks, sending temperatures to 40C and above.

The fire emergency has thrown a spotlight not only on climate change but also trends that have left Spain's countryside vulnerable.

Castile and Leon suffers from decades of rural exodus, an ageing population, and a decline of farming and livestock grazing that once helped keep forests clear of tinder.

Strong winds that had spread the flames for weeks had weakened recently.

Barcones said there were still 18 active wildfires, with all but one classified at operational level 2, meaning they represent a danger to people and property.

She said she was particularly concerned about a fire in Iguena, in northwest Castile and Leon.

Even so, "the overall feeling is that it is improving, going in the right direction, and that less is burning," she said.

While numerous villages remain evacuated for their inhabitants' safety, many residents have been able to return to their properties since Friday.

The fires have fuelled accusations that politicians mishandled the crisis.

The main opposition party, the conservative Popular Party, has accused Socialist Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez of having withheld aid to damaged regions where its officials govern.

According to EFFIS data analysed by AFP, Spain is one of four EU countries experiencing its worst year for wildfires since statistics began in 2006.

The other three are Cyprus, Germany and Slovakia.

Scientists say climate change is driving longer, more intense and more frequent heatwaves worldwide.

Lower humidity in the air, vegetation and soil makes it easier for wildfires to ignite and harder to control once they spread.

urn:contentItem:6GNB-4G53-RTR1-61CP-00000-00This year, 475 forest fires have been registered, according to Indeci.2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisThis year, 475 forest fires have been registered, according to Indeci.

475 forest fires have been reported this year, according to Indeci.In algos alone, 254 fires were reported. Regions such as Cusco, Ancash, Puno, Ucayali, Apurimac and Pasco are among the most affected. Some areas are the last remaining reserves with low human disturbance and high biodiversity.

Hitman riddles Indonesian embassy diplomat with bullets in Lince, Peru

Earthquake in Ica: 5.0 magnitude quake shook Pisco, according to IGP

Óscar Chumpitaz
Between January and August 2025, the Andean and Amazonian grasslands and forests of six regions of the country were the scene of 475 forest fires, some of an unprecedented magnitude in the last five years.


According to a report carried out by the National Institute of Civil Defense through the processing of satellite images and field work, the fires affected thousands of hectares mainly in Cusco, Ancash, Puno, Ucayali, Apurimac and Pasco.
Some of these devastated areas constitute one of the last reserves of temperate forests with low human disturbance and high biodiversity.
Authorities warn that these phenomena, far from being an isolated event, are linked to human action and to a climate crisis that is underestimated. They also stressed that, if the necessary measures are not taken, the forests could suffer irreversible damage.
In August alone , 254 fires were reported, due to the conditions of the dry season, with lower humidity levels, greater solar intensity and strong winds that favor the spread of fire, according to the Indeci report.
In recent days, Indeci confirmed that a total of six forest fires were extinguished in the districts of Sihuas (Ancash), Iguaín (Ayacucho), Nueva Requena (Ucayali), Mollepata (Cusco), Las Piedras (Madre de Dios) and Cayma (Arequipa).
Another fire was also controlled in San Jerónimo (Apurímac), where the flames consumed natural cover without causing damage to the life or health of the population.
Katy Rivera Montalván, Indeci's Risk and Disaster Management specialist, highlighted that the entity, through the National Emergency Operations Center (COEN), maintains permanent monitoring and coordinates actions with the Regional, Provincial and District Emergency Operations Centers (COER), as well as with local authorities.
In this way, he says, an immediate and coordinated response to large-scale emergencies is ensured.
In the event of a forest fire, Rivera stressed that the population should not intervene directly if they do not have the appropriate training and equipment.
"The main recommendation is to immediately inform local authorities and first response entities, such as the Volunteer Fire Department (116) and the National Police (105), so that they can activate their protocols of attention," he said.
INDECI RECOMMENDS
Likewise, the Indeci representative urged citizens to take preventive measures to reduce the risk of new disasters.
"It is necessary to avoid lighting fires outdoors near forests or plantations, not to burn vegetable waste or bushes, to completely extinguish bonfires or wood stoves, and not to accumulate flammable materials such as straw or wood, which serve as fuel for fire," she recommended.
During an emergency, the population should remain calm and follow the instructions of local authorities and response entities, including firefighters, the National Police, the Armed Forces, the National Forestry Service (SERFOR) and community brigades.
Indeci, attached to the Ministry of Defense, emphasizes that responsible and coordinated participation is essential to protect life, ecosystems and reduce the impacts of forest fires in our country.

urn:contentItem:6GNJ-3DS3-RRT2-H3Y9-00000-00President Boluarte made official the creation of San Pedro de Chonta Regional Conservation Area2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisPresident Boluarte made official the creation of San Pedro de Chonta Regional Conservation Area

"Today we are called together by a common and urgent commitment: to protect biodiversity, preserve the ecosystems of our country and ensure sustainable development," said the President. "Growing while caring for nature is not a secondary option, it is the only possible way to build a fairer Peru with a better future," she emphasized.


With the publication of Supreme Decree No. 016-2025-MINAM, the Government established the creation of the San Pedro de Chonta RCA, which comprises 51 888 hectares in the districts of Cholón and Huacrachuco, Marañón province. "This achievement transcends the administrative: it means safeguarding water sources, protecting biodiversity and guaranteeing the wellbeing of the communities," the president emphasized.
This area is home to 575 species of flora and 226 species of fauna, including the spectacled bear, the yellow-tailed choro monkey and birds such as the dorsidora tanager. "That is why its protection is so necessary and vital from the central, regional and local government and from the population," he stressed.
Ecological and Economic Zoning
During the ceremony, the President also led the signing of the agreement between the Executive (Ministry of Environment) and the Regional Government of Lima to implement the Ecological and Economic Zoning (ZEE) and the Integrated Management of Coastal Marine Areas.
"We are not talking about an isolated technical action, but a compass that will guide land use planning, direct investments towards safe and sustainable zones, and allow us to protect our resources with intelligence and foresight," he said.
With this agreement, the Lima region will have a strategic tool to plan the growth of its nine provinces, 128 districts and more than 32,000 square kilometers without compromising the conservation of its natural resources.
The third axis of the ceremony focused on forest fire prevention. In this context, the President recalled the damages caused by the 2024 fires and presented the agreement signed between the Ministries of Environment, Agrarian Development and Irrigation, the National Service of Natural Areas Protected by the State (SERNANP), the National Forestry and Wildlife Service (SERFOR) and the Regional Government of Ucayali to strengthen the response to this type of emergency.
"We have signed an agreement to join capacities, resources and experience, in order to guide the population not to burn in forest areas, prevent fires, respond effectively and restore damaged ecosystems", he remarked.
In this context, she also participated in the symbolic delivery of clothing and equipment for park rangers and forest brigades. The head of state said that these actions are part of an integral vision of the country's development.
The Ministers of Environment and Agrarian Development and Irrigation, Juan Carlos Castro Vargas and Ángel Manero Campos, respectively, as well as Rosa Vásquez Cuadrado, Regional Governor of Lima; Manuel Gambini Rupay, Regional Governor of Ucayali; Antonio Pulgar Lucas, Regional Governor of Huánuco participated in the activity.

urn:contentItem:6GNB-4FX3-RT5B-B05N-00000-00Fire in a forest reserve in Bolivia: "This is going to get out of control".2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisFire in a forest reserve in Bolivia: "This is going to get out of control".


A forest fire in a protected area in Bolivia is causing concern because of the advance of the fire and the logistical difficulties faced by firefighters in combating it. The Ñembi Guasu reserve, located in the southeastern part of the country, in the department of Santa Cruz, has already lost more than 1,000 hectares of forest to the fire, which is believed to have originated in a waste burning that quickly spread to forested areas.


Local authorities have requested reinforcements to assist the firefighters, who face logistical limitations such as the lack of machinery and fuel for their operation. Alejandro Arambiza, in charge of the protected area, indicated that they only have one tractor to make lines of defense and that its use is conditioned by the scarce supply of diesel in the country.
Diego Quinteros, head of Environment and Risk Management for the municipality of Roboré, asked for help to prevent the fires from spreading. "We need help from the governor's office and international organizations, because otherwise this could get out of control, as happened last year," he said in an interview with Unitel channel.
The Mayor's Office of Roboré sent a commission to the city of Santa Cruz de la Sierra to request national and international aid. According to local press reports, there are 85 people fighting the fire, including park rangers, volunteer firefighters, army soldiers and residents of nearby communities.
The Ñembi Guasu reserve is a protected area of great ecological importance located in the southeastern part of the department of Santa Cruz, between the municipalities of Roboré and Charagua. It was created with the objective of conserving more than one million hectares of dry forests and Chaco savannas. This territory is home to a wide biodiversity, including emblematic species of the country such as the jaguar, tapir and anteater, and also links three eco-regions Chaco, Chiquitanía and Pantanal.
"As happened last year."
Quinteros expressed his fear of fire out of control due to the ecological crisis that Bolivia suffered in 2024, when forest fires consumed more than 12.6 million hectares, an area comparable to that of Nicaragua.
Prolonged drought, combined with high temperatures and the practice of burning land for land clearing and agricultural crops, created the conditions for the spread of fire that lasted for more than four months.
A report by Fundación Tierra - with support from the TeamEurope Environmental Initiative (European Union and Sweden) - identified the uncontrolled expansion of mechanized agriculture as a structural cause of the fires, as well as weaknesses in integrated fire management and deficiencies in the oversight of environmental authorities.
The 2024 fires not only impacted biodiversity, but also affected several rural communities whose livelihoods were compromised. In several areas, crop losses, livestock damage and problems of access to water were reported, which increased the vulnerability of populations already affected by the drought.
In several capital cities, air pollution reached unhealthy levels for more than a month, forcing the suspension of public activities and school classes for several days.
The government's response included declaring an ecological environmental pause and a national disaster to expedite the arrival of international support brigades when the fire had already consumed seven million hectares.

urn:contentItem:6GN5-M3J3-RSX1-72F5-00000-00Cool weather, wildfire smoke blanket North Dakota; frost possible in some areas this week2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisBPg. 001Cool weather, wildfire smoke blanket North Dakota; frost possible in some areas this weekBLAKE NICHOLSON Bismarck Tribune

A cold front that passed through the Northern Plains early Tuesday is bringing fall-like temperatures to North Dakota this week, and possibly even frost to some areas.

Meanwhile, smoke from Canadian wildfires followed the front, bringing unhealthy air to western and central North Dakota once again this summer.

Late-summer cooldown

High temperatures in the state from Wednesday into the weekend are forecast mainly in the 50s and 60s, with overnight lows in the 30s and 40s, according to the National Weather Service. The forecast for Bismarck-Mandan calls for highs mainly in the 60s -- a sharp drop from Monday's high of 82 degrees -- with overnight temps as cool as the lower 40s. Those conditions are more typical of early October.

The first official day of autumn is Sept. 22. In most of western and central North Dakota the first 32-degree freeze usually occurs between Sept. 21 and Sept. 30, with a few areas in the southwest seeing it from Sept. 11-20, according to the Weather Service. However, there is the potential for frost and possibly some freezing temperatures later this week in some spots, forecasters said.

AccuWeather Meteorologist Elizabeth Danco reported that the brisk and cool weather will impact millions of people in the Northern Plains and Great Lakes regions, but that breezes or cloud cover will likely prevent any widespread frost or freezing at night.

"However, exceptions are possible where the sky clears and winds calm for several hours," she wrote. "Where frost does occur, it could spell the end of the growing season for people with backyard gardens."

The Weather Service office in Bismarck urged people to watch for any frost advisories or freeze warnings. If any are issued, people should cover garden vegetation and bring outdoor potted plants indoors, forecasters said.

Return of smoke

Wildfire smoke has been an issue off and on all summer in North Dakota. With the latest surge, near-surface smoke could linger through at least Wednesday, reducing visibility and creating unhealthy conditions for some people, according to the Weather Service.

Air quality in the western half of North Dakota on Tuesday was rated "moderate" to "unhealthy for sensitive groups." North Dakota's Department of Environmental Quality cautioned residents about the conditions, and urged people who are sensitive to the conditions to limit outdoors activities when air quality is poor.

There have been more than 5,000 fires north of the border this year burning more than 20 million acres, according to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre. That's a total area about half the size of North Dakota. Many of the fires listed as "out of control" are in the North Dakota-neighboring provinces of Saskatchewan and Manitoba.

Information on wildfires and air quality is on the DEQ website, at bit.ly/3OhrD7E. The federal Environmental Protection Agency’s map of fire and smoke conditions is at https://fire.airnow.gov/. The AirNow mobile phone app, and many other weather apps, also include air quality information. AirNow is a partnership of federal and state agencies including the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

urn:contentItem:6GN5-YB73-RS5G-81XG-00000-00New Findings from Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics Update Understanding of Engineering (Scheduling and Route Planning for Forests Rescue: Applications With a Novel Ant Colony Optimization Algorithm)2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisENGINEERINGNew Findings from Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics Update Understanding of Engineering (Scheduling and Route Planning for Forests Rescue: Applications With a Novel Ant Colony Optimization Algorithm)


2025 SEP 03 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Math Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on Engineering. According to news reporting from Nanjing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "With the increasing frequency and intensity of forest fires due to global climate change and human activities, timely and efficient fire rescue has become critical. Helicopter inspections are a preventive measure that significantly improves fire incident resolution efficiency."


Financial supporters for this research include National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC), Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities, The 333 talent project in Jiangsu Province (China).
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, "Existing approaches to helicopter route planning often focus on single-stage scheduling (either offline pre-planning or online reactive adjustments), which fail to dynamically balance pre-scheduled routes with real-time emergency responses. Additionally, traditional optimization algorithms like the Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) suffer from premature convergence and instability caused by overly random initial search solutions and restrictive tabu lists in later search phases. To address these gaps, this paper proposes a two-stage dynamic path planning model that integrates offline pre-scheduling with online adaptive adjustments. The model first optimizes inspection routes for all points using a novel Improved Ant Colony Optimization (IACO) algorithm, which introduces dynamic pheromone initialization and a stage-dependent pheromone update strategy to enhance exploration-exploitation balance. During real-time operations, when emergencies occur, the model dynamically dispatches the nearest available helicopter while reconfiguring remaining inspection paths. Two representative scenarios validate the model's effectiveness: (1) independent regional dispatch where a helicopter adjusts its route to handle an emergency within its assigned cluster, and (2) cross-region joint dispatch involving multi-helicopter coordination across clusters. The IACO algorithm outperforms traditional ACO by reducing total flight distances by up to 4.1 % in offline planning and improving emergency response efficiency by 7.3 % in dynamic scenarios."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This work provides a robust framework for balancing routine inspections with agile emergency management in forest fire rescue operations."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Scheduling and Route Planning for Forests Rescue: Applications With a Novel Ant Colony Optimization Algorithm. Engineering Applications of Artificial Intelligence, 2025;155. Engineering Applications of Artificial Intelligence can be contacted at: Pergamon-elsevier Science Ltd, The Boulevard, Langford Lane, Kidlington, Oxford OX5 1GB, England. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Engineering Applications of Artificial Intelligence - www.journals.elsevier.com/engineering-applications-of-artificial-intelligence/)
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Naiming Xie, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, College of Economics & Management, Nanjing 211100, People's Republic of China.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.engappai.2025.111042. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Nanjing, People's Republic of China, Asia, Engineering, Algorithms, Ant Colony Optimization, Biological Factors, Emerging Technologies, Machine Learning, Pheromones, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics.

urn:contentItem:6GM3-DTX3-RW6K-W3GN-00000-00EU faces worst wildfire season on record as over 1mn hectares burn2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisEU faces worst wildfire season on record as over 1mn hectares burn

The European Union is enduring its most severe wildfire season since records began, with more than 1.01mn hectares of land scorched so far this year, surpassing previous highs and raising concerns over climate preparedness and environmental management across the bloc.

According to data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), fires have burned 1,016,000 hectares of land since January - an area larger than Cyprus and equivalent to roughly one-third of Belgium, Politico reports.

It is the first time the EU has crossed the 1mn hectare threshold since EFFIS began tracking fires in 2006. The previous worst year, 2017, recorded just under 988,000 hectares burned. As reported by bne IntelliNews, Europe is facing an unprecedented heatwave this year as the Climate Crisis accelerates faster than scientists predicted. The Paris targets of holding warming to 1.5°C  has already been missed and the world is on course to warm by 2.7C-3.1C, according to the United Nations' Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).

Nearly two-thirds of the total area burned was lost after August 5, when EFFIS data recorded only 380,000 hectares affected. The sharp increase in fire activity has been concentrated primarily on the Iberian Peninsula, with Spain and Portugal among the worst-hit countries.

Spain alone accounts for more than 400,000 hectares burned. In Portugal, more than 270,000 hectares - equivalent to 3% of the country's entire territory - have been consumed by flames. According to government figures, this marks the worst fire season in Spain since 1994, based on records that date back to the 1960s.

The fires have been driven by extreme heat in recent weeks, which has dried out forests and left large regions of the peninsula highly flammable. Scientists warn that climate change is increasing the frequency and intensity of heatwaves and droughts, further elevating the risk of wildfires.

However, experts point to human factors as the principal cause of the devastation. "The main driver of the catastrophic fires in Spain and Portugal is an overabundance of flammable vegetation on abandoned land and authorities' failure to take preventive measures," researchers noted.

In response, Spain's special prosecutor for environmental issues has opened an investigation into the country's lack of fire prevention plans.

EFFIS data also indicates that the EU could be approaching a record level of carbon dioxide emissions from wildfires, as large-scale blazes release substantial volumes of planet-warming pollution.

urn:contentItem:6GK6-7343-RV75-305W-00000-00EU faces worst wildfire season on record as over 1mn hectares burn2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisEU faces worst wildfire season on record as over 1mn hectares burn

The European Union is enduring its most severe wildfire season since records began, with more than 1.01mn hectares of land scorched so far this year, surpassing previous highs and raising concerns over climate preparedness and environmental management across the bloc.

According to data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), fires have burned 1,016,000 hectares of land since January - an area larger than Cyprus and equivalent to roughly one-third of Belgium, Politico reports.

It is the first time the EU has crossed the 1mn hectare threshold since EFFIS began tracking fires in 2006. The previous worst year, 2017, recorded just under 988,000 hectares burned. As reported by bne IntelliNews, Europe is facing an unprecedented heatwave this year as the Climate Crisis accelerates faster than scientists predicted. The Paris targets of holding warming to 1.5°C  has already been missed and the world is on course to warm by 2.7C-3.1C, according to the United Nations' Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).

Nearly two-thirds of the total area burned was lost after August 5, when EFFIS data recorded only 380,000 hectares affected. The sharp increase in fire activity has been concentrated primarily on the Iberian Peninsula, with Spain and Portugal among the worst-hit countries.

Spain alone accounts for more than 400,000 hectares burned. In Portugal, more than 270,000 hectares - equivalent to 3% of the country's entire territory - have been consumed by flames. According to government figures, this marks the worst fire season in Spain since 1994, based on records that date back to the 1960s.

The fires have been driven by extreme heat in recent weeks, which has dried out forests and left large regions of the peninsula highly flammable. Scientists warn that climate change is increasing the frequency and intensity of heatwaves and droughts, further elevating the risk of wildfires.

However, experts point to human factors as the principal cause of the devastation. "The main driver of the catastrophic fires in Spain and Portugal is an overabundance of flammable vegetation on abandoned land and authorities' failure to take preventive measures," researchers noted.

In response, Spain's special prosecutor for environmental issues has opened an investigation into the country's lack of fire prevention plans.

EFFIS data also indicates that the EU could be approaching a record level of carbon dioxide emissions from wildfires, as large-scale blazes release substantial volumes of planet-warming pollution.

urn:contentItem:6GK6-7343-RV75-3018-00000-00EU faces worst wildfire season on record as over 1mn hectares burn2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisEU faces worst wildfire season on record as over 1mn hectares burn

The European Union is enduring its most severe wildfire season since records began, with more than 1.01mn hectares of land scorched so far this year, surpassing previous highs and raising concerns over climate preparedness and environmental management across the bloc.

According to data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), fires have burned 1,016,000 hectares of land since January - an area larger than Cyprus and equivalent to roughly one-third of Belgium, Politico reports.

It is the first time the EU has crossed the 1mn hectare threshold since EFFIS began tracking fires in 2006. The previous worst year, 2017, recorded just under 988,000 hectares burned. As reported by bne IntelliNews, Europe is facing an unprecedented heatwave this year as the Climate Crisis accelerates faster than scientists predicted. The Paris targets of holding warming to 1.5°C  has already been missed and the world is on course to warm by 2.7C-3.1C, according to the United Nations' Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).

Nearly two-thirds of the total area burned was lost after August 5, when EFFIS data recorded only 380,000 hectares affected. The sharp increase in fire activity has been concentrated primarily on the Iberian Peninsula, with Spain and Portugal among the worst-hit countries.

Spain alone accounts for more than 400,000 hectares burned. In Portugal, more than 270,000 hectares - equivalent to 3% of the country's entire territory - have been consumed by flames. According to government figures, this marks the worst fire season in Spain since 1994, based on records that date back to the 1960s.

The fires have been driven by extreme heat in recent weeks, which has dried out forests and left large regions of the peninsula highly flammable. Scientists warn that climate change is increasing the frequency and intensity of heatwaves and droughts, further elevating the risk of wildfires.

However, experts point to human factors as the principal cause of the devastation. "The main driver of the catastrophic fires in Spain and Portugal is an overabundance of flammable vegetation on abandoned land and authorities' failure to take preventive measures," researchers noted.

In response, Spain's special prosecutor for environmental issues has opened an investigation into the country's lack of fire prevention plans.

EFFIS data also indicates that the EU could be approaching a record level of carbon dioxide emissions from wildfires, as large-scale blazes release substantial volumes of planet-warming pollution.
