urn:contentItem:6GK6-7343-RV75-3078-00000-00EU faces worst wildfire season on record as over 1mn hectares burn2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisEU faces worst wildfire season on record as over 1mn hectares burn

The European Union is enduring its most severe wildfire season since records began, with more than 1.01mn hectares of land scorched so far this year, surpassing previous highs and raising concerns over climate preparedness and environmental management across the bloc.

According to data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), fires have burned 1,016,000 hectares of land since January - an area larger than Cyprus and equivalent to roughly one-third of Belgium, Politico reports.

It is the first time the EU has crossed the 1mn hectare threshold since EFFIS began tracking fires in 2006. The previous worst year, 2017, recorded just under 988,000 hectares burned. As reported by bne IntelliNews, Europe is facing an unprecedented heatwave this year as the Climate Crisis accelerates faster than scientists predicted. The Paris targets of holding warming to 1.5°C  has already been missed and the world is on course to warm by 2.7C-3.1C, according to the United Nations' Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).

Nearly two-thirds of the total area burned was lost after August 5, when EFFIS data recorded only 380,000 hectares affected. The sharp increase in fire activity has been concentrated primarily on the Iberian Peninsula, with Spain and Portugal among the worst-hit countries.

Spain alone accounts for more than 400,000 hectares burned. In Portugal, more than 270,000 hectares - equivalent to 3% of the country's entire territory - have been consumed by flames. According to government figures, this marks the worst fire season in Spain since 1994, based on records that date back to the 1960s.

The fires have been driven by extreme heat in recent weeks, which has dried out forests and left large regions of the peninsula highly flammable. Scientists warn that climate change is increasing the frequency and intensity of heatwaves and droughts, further elevating the risk of wildfires.

However, experts point to human factors as the principal cause of the devastation. "The main driver of the catastrophic fires in Spain and Portugal is an overabundance of flammable vegetation on abandoned land and authorities' failure to take preventive measures," researchers noted.

In response, Spain's special prosecutor for environmental issues has opened an investigation into the country's lack of fire prevention plans.

EFFIS data also indicates that the EU could be approaching a record level of carbon dioxide emissions from wildfires, as large-scale blazes release substantial volumes of planet-warming pollution.

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G1B3-RS1P-J4R8-00000-00The fire business in Castilla y León: Mañueco distributes 110 million among twenty companies2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisThe fire business in Castilla y León: Mañueco distributes 110 million among twenty companies


Forty percent of the forest firefighters in Castilla y León work for private companies that share the tenders for the prevention and extinction of fires, another 40% are employees of the public Tragsa and the remaining 20% depend on the regional government. These are percentages wielded by the unions when they denounce the precariousness of these templates, in the front line against fire these days of catastrophic fires in the western third of the country. According to the state coordinator of environmental agents of CCOO, Jorge Nieto, the privatization of the operation is one of the causes of the "third-world" conditions in which the forest firefighters of Castilla y León work.


In fact, about twenty companies are the successful bidders of the multiple contracts tendered by the Ministry of Environment, as can be seen by visiting the State Procurement Platform. If we add up the amounts tendered only for the fire prevention and extinction contracts in the years 2024 and 2025 and for those signed in 2023 still in force, the Government of Alfonso Fernández Mañueco has paid 108.91 million euros to these companies, both for the ground crews -81.64 million- and for the ELIF (Specialists in the Fight against Forest Fires) crews -16.56 million- and for the night crews -10.71 million-. Castilla y León pays 45.43 million Euros for the provision of aerial means, including airplanes and helicopters.
Among these twenty companies there are two national companies: Acciona Medio Ambiente and Eulen. The former received 11.66 million euros from the Castile and Leon Regional Government, which makes the subsidiary of the construction company owned by the Entrecanales family the second largest contractor, behind only Oficina Técnica Demontes SL, a company from Valladolid that has also been contracted by the Galician Regional Government. As part of a Temporary Joint Venture (UTE) with the giant Avincis, it won a tender to provide aerial firefighting means for 4.34 million euros in 2023. From the Castilian Government, Demontes has won contracts worth 15.05 million euros, including three to supply it with ELIF crews and as many for night crews.
The Eulen service company's bite is smaller: 2.21 million euros.
Local companies
The third in volume of awards is another Valladolid firm, Integra (Ingeniería y Técnicas Globales de Resolución Ambiental SLU), with 10.37 million euros. Rebofosa (Repoblación y Bosquetes Forestales SA), a company from Zamora, also got 9.73 million from the Junta de Castilla y León. And like Demontes, and also as part of a joint venture called Helicópteros de Galicia, it won, together with Airworks Helicopters SL, two multi-annual contracts of 21.86 and 8.78 million euros from the Xunta. Fifth in the ranking is the Murcian company Orthem Servicios y Actuaciones Ambientales SL, which won 9.03 million in contracts from Mañueco's government. Estudios y Trabajos Forestales SL (Estrafo), based in Salamanca, is next in the ranking with another 7.21 million.
The rest of the awardees are mostly companies from Castilla y León and Madrid. Crece Conservación del Patrimonio Natural SL is a company from Burgos, which has contracts worth 5.84 million euros. Talher SA, from Madrid, won 4.89 million; Foresa (Forestación y Repoblación SA), another firm from Valladolid, was awarded contracts worth 4.67 million. IGM, Ingeniería y Gestión Medioambiental SL -4.3 million-, is from Madrid. Emelesa -1.22 million-, from León. The Riojan company Euroservicios y Obras Forestales SA -1.9 million- is the exception, because Inforest Medio Ambiente SLe -3.84 million- is based in Valladolid and Resinera Soriana SL -2.98 million-, in Soria.
The contracts for the ELIF and the night crews are shared by an even smaller number of companies: only five. The aforementioned Demontes, Estrafo, Talher, Orthem and IGM.
The failure of private management in Galicia and Madrid
Castilla y León is thus a special case as far as the management of firefighting operations is concerned. In Galicia, the regional fire stations - which are in charge of urban fires, but go to any other if required - were run by private companies until 2023, when those of Ourense returned to public hands. Before that, in 2019, those of Lugo, A Coruña and Pontevedra had already done so. There were a total of 23, which were awarded to private companies during the last government of Manuel Fraga. The main contractor was Veicar, a bodywork company that managed 14 parks and against which there were complaints from its workers due to their terrible working conditions and the inefficiency of the service they provided. Now they are managed directly by consortiums that integrate the Xunta, the Diputación and the corresponding City Council.
The privatization of the forest fire prevention and extinction services in the Community of Madrid was not very successful either. After more than 20 years in charge of two private companies, Matinsa, a subsidiary of Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas (FCC) which also managed regional parks in Galicia, and Infosa, in 2022 the management passed to the public Tragsa. The government of Isabel Díaz Ayuso signed a management contract with it for 107.06 million euros, partly financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD). The public company took over 448 workers. The reason for the reversion in Madrid was the same as in Galicia: the protests of the forest firefighters about the working conditions and the poor quality of the service offered by Matinsa and Infosa had been constant over the years.
Even so, Madrid's forest firefighters are still mobilized. They began a strike on July 15, which they have only interrupted during the wave of fires in August. They are demanding a new agreement to improve their salaries, frozen since 2010, and to take into account the danger, hardship and toxicity of their work: they want the same working conditions as the Forest Fire Reinforcement Brigades (BRIF), which depend on the central administration. The Community of Madrid has just offered them those included in the new Tragsa agreement, recently published, where they are granted a 2.5% salary increase.

urn:contentItem:6GS3-NX13-RSNN-34B1-00000-00LETTERS2025-09-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisEPg. 002LETTERS

ICE NEEDS TO CHILL WHEN IT COMES TO FIRE CREWS

We have a severe shortage of wildland firefighters, with more than a quarter of U.S. Forest Service firefighting positions unfilled even as wildfires grow larger and fire seasons grow much longer.

Yet, as reported, Trump's ICE agents now barge into backwoods fire lines, arresting immigrants who risk their lives at one of America's toughest, most physically demanding, unhealthy jobs. Is this how we solve our firefighter shortage?

Shame on ICE for disrupting our fire crews in the midst of fighting the state's largest forest fire, then carting off firefighters to concentration camps without a word to their families.

We need more firefighters, not less. Why should we care whether they have a green card handy as long as they fill our urgent need for strong people willing to swing a Pulaski, eat smoke, and put their lives and lungs in danger for weeks at a stretch on blazing mountainsides to keep our communities safe? These seem like decent qualifications for citizenship.

When it comes to ICE and fire, let's hope ICE can be a little more chill.

DAVID CAMP

SPOKANE

BAUMGARTNER AND CLIMATE CHANGE

There is a consensus among climate scientists that the burning of fossil fuels is responsible for raising CO2 levels in our atmosphere that will result in a warming and changing climate that will affect everything from agricultural productivity, weather related disasters, immigration and insurance rates. There has been a political consensus since 1988 that climate change is a global problem that requires a global response. Our country signed the Paris Climate Agreement to respond to this global problem. In 2016 and in 2020, President Trump, with the support of Republican senators, House members and business interests pulled the U.S. out of the Paris Agreement, claiming that climate change is a hoax and is not a serious problem without providing evidence to support these claims.

If you are interested in knowing what Rep. Michael Baumgartner's understanding of climate change is you are out of luck. Apparently, your representative doesn't care to state his position on climate change. Nothing is posted on his website and if you call or write requesting to know his position you will not receive a reply. I've tried.

How can we as citizens solve problems that are common to all of us if we can't as citizens acknowledge that an obvious common problem exists? If Rep. Baumgartner shares our president's assertion that climate change is a hoax, it is incumbent on Rep. Baumgartner to provide evidence that refutes the longstanding consensus of climate scientists around the world. Where do you stand Rep. Baumgartner?

KENT RINNE

OTIS ORCHARDS

THANKFUL FOR BAUMGARTNER AND HIS BILL ON NITAZENES

Thanks to Rep. Baumgartner for recognizing the dangers of nitazenes, a class of synthetic opiods up to 40 times stronger than fentanyl. He reached across the aisle and joined forces with Eugene Vindman (D-Va.) to introduce a bill aimed at curbing the rise in this dangerous drug. Rep. Baumgartner makes it his business to help Eastern Washington by protecting those who are struggling with addiction (that they don't get addicted to something worse) and the rest of us whose hearts break to watch it.

Rep. Baumgartner is in tune with the concerns that real citizens have in our region with its easy access to drugs and rampant abuse. Thanks to him for focusing on the things that really matter to us here. Thanks to him for being willing to take action!

HEATHER ROY-TING

SPOKANE

urn:contentItem:6GP6-0J33-RT5S-N3X6-00000-00The majority of fire cases were opened in Santa Cruz.2025-09-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisThe majority of fire cases were opened in Santa Cruz.


While firefighters are fighting fires, authorities are conducting investigations into the use of fire. The Vice Minister of Civil Defense, Juan Carlos Calvimontes, informed this Sunday that so far 89 processes have been opened in the country, between administrative and criminal, most of them in the department of Santa Cruz.


"The ABT (Authority of Fiscalization and Social Control of Forests and Land) until today (Sunday) has initiated 89 processes. Of which 74 are administrative and 15 criminal. The processes in private property are 55 and in communities are 19", he explained in Bolivia Tv.
These investigations have been opened in various parts of the country. Now, the corresponding authorities must continue with the process to determine sanctions, in the corresponding cases.
PROCESSES
"Santa Cruz is the department where there are more processes, 31 administrative processes, 13 criminal processes, in total 44. We are talking that in La Paz there are 18 administrative processes, in Beni, 13 and the rest of the country 12", said the vice minister.
Calvimontes regretted that last year, despite the fact that several processes were also opened during the fire season, the sanctions were light. It is hoped that this year penalties can be given in all open cases and thus help to stop irresponsible activities that may lead to fires.
"Let's hope that this year exemplary sanctions can be given to those who are originating the fires and that they do not go unpunished as last year, (that of) 176 processes, only six came to have sentences, we could say, mild, which were from one month to three months and an owner in Otuquis was given an area so he can reforest, we do not know if he has done so, however, these measures were extremely mild," he noted.
FOREST FIRES
In addition, the authority recalled that one of the measures applied by the Agro-environmental Court calls the prosecutor's offices to activate ex officio investigations. He recalled, in this context, that this year there should be no fires because there is an ecological pause in Bolivia.
"The Agro-environmental Court, within the precautionary measures activated, instructs the departmental prosecutors and specialized prosecutors to initiate ex officio investigations and apply the law in force at this time. Let us not forget that there is an ecological pause and that says zero fires, zero use of fire and therefore there should be zero fires," he said.
He also stressed that another of the provisions of the court was to declare a disaster in the Noel Kempff Mercado National Park, in the department of Santa Cruz, affected by the fire. However, he said, so far this decision has not been complied with.
"The Agro-environmental Court has issued precautionary measures and one of them, for example, to protect the Noel Kempff Mercado Park reserve. There it has expressly requested that this reserve be declared a forest fire disaster. Surely at the appropriate time, an evaluation will have to be made as to why the Agro-environmental Tribunal is not complying with these instructions," he said.
He added that Law 602 delegates the responsibilities of each government agency in this type of events.
Calvimontes assured that the Government carries out aerial patrols and gathers information on the sites where fires are occurring. Although up to this Sunday it is reported that all the fires have been completely controlled, there is still concern for the protected areas, since several of them have registered fires.
For this reason, it was ratified that monitoring is permanent both there and in the rest of the country.

urn:contentItem:6GN4-5DG3-S59F-W1JN-00000-00Arequipa: Thieves disguised as policemen rob hotel and steal more than S/11 thousand2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisArequipa: Thieves disguised as policemen rob hotel and steal more than S/11 thousand

Listen to this article
Fear once again gripped the residents of Los Incas Avenue, in the heart of Cercado de Arequipa, after a violent assault on the night of Monday, September 1 at the Kaprichos hostel.


A gang of heavily armed criminals entered the place around 11:00 p.m., reduced the barracks keeper and seized more than 10 thousand soles in cash. To escape, they shot in the air and at vehicles parked in the area, causing panic among residents and passers-by.
Imagen Perú Tue, 02/09/2025 - 18:45 Forest fire advances on railroad track near Machu Picchu
The fire is registered on the border between the districts of Ollantaytambo and Machu Picchu, about 15 kilometers from the Historic Sanctuary of the same name.
PERÚ21 Newsroom
According to initial police investigations, the five thieves arrived in a white Toyota RAV pickup truck. They were wearing vests and caps with Peruvian National Police (PNP) insignia, which allowed them to blend in and carry out the robbery quickly.
Witnesses reported that the owner of the establishment had to take refuge in a bathroom to avoid being hit by bullets, while the barracks manager was threatened. After seizing the proceeds, the criminals escaped in the vehicle that was waiting for them at the door, shooting in the middle of the street.
The projectiles hit two parked vans: one with license plate ADA-315 and the other with license plate AMG-655. Neighbors said that the roar of the shots unleashed scenes of terror in the vicinity of the Bicentennial Bridge, where at that time families and students were passing by.
In response to the call for help, Radio Patrol officers went to the place and a brief exchange of gunshots took place. However, the assailants managed to evade the police siege plan and fled towards the Pachacútec sector, in Cerro Colorado, where their trail was finally lost.

The same criminal gang?
This event has aroused suspicions that it is the same organization that days before perpetrated another robbery in a store with the same name in José Luis Bustamante y Rivero. On that occasion, three armed criminals took more than 3 thousand soles after threatening the manager and smashing the counter partition.
The use of firearms, the violence against the workers and the speed of the escape reinforce the hypothesis that it was an organized gang operating under the same modus operandi.

Two people involved in the robbery are captured
One day after the robbery, on Tuesday, September 2, the National Police managed to capture two alleged members of the gang: Jonathan Bruno Díaz (36) and Luis Trinidad (28), both from Lima and with criminal records.
The intervention took place in the vicinity of Paseo Central shopping center, near Ernesto Gunther bridge, when the subjects were inside a cab by application. A backpack, a suitcase and a firearm wrapped in aluminum foil were found in their possession.
According to preliminary information, the detainees were linked not only to the Kaprichos hostel robbery, but also to other recent robberies in Arequipa. One of them has already served time in prison for similar crimes, which reinforces the suspicion that this is a gang that came from the capital to carry out robberies in the White City.

urn:contentItem:6GMW-TY93-SJ0W-W4BG-00000-00Gangneung enforces stricter water limits amid worsening drought 2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisGangneung enforces stricter water limits amid worsening drought

The South Korean government has stepped up emergency drought measures in Gangneung, Gangwon Province, as the city's main source of tap and industrial water continues to drop to record lows daily, forcing its citizens to endure strict water restrictions.

According to the Ministry of Interior and Safety on Tuesday, the water storage level at the Obong Reservoir ? which supplies nearly 87 percent of the city's household water ? fell to 14.4 percent as of 6 p.m., Monday, down 0.3 percentage point from a day earlier.

The decline prompted authorities to escalate restrictions, including partially shutting off household meters by 75 percent, closing access to 47 public restrooms, and halting operations at three public swimming pools. According to the Gangneung city government, the city first began shutting off household meters less than two weeks ago by 50 percent, on Aug. 20.

To coordinate relief efforts, the government has mobilized an interagency emergency response task force dedicated to handling drought conditions, comprising the Interior Ministry, the Environment Ministry, the Gangwon provincial government and the Gangneung city government.

The task force was formed after President Lee Jae Myung declared a "state of national disaster" on Aug. 30, which enabled the central government to mobilize all relevant manpower and resources nationwide to aid the city in drought relief. The declaration also raised the government's emergency response posture to Level 2 under the Central Disaster and Safety Countermeasures Headquarters' system.

In Korea, a Level 2 response entails the full-scale mobilization of all administrative resources, with the provincial vice governor serving as the head of the headquarters.

As of Tuesday, authorities have deployed 112 vehicles to tackle the city's water shortage issue, including 71 fire department water tankers and four military water tankers, to deliver up to 5,071 metric tons of water to Obong Reservoir and Hongje Water Purification Plant.

An additional 20,000 tons of alternative water sources have also been secured, including 5,000 tons of underground water in Gangneung and 1,800 tons of water from nearby cities, including Hongcheon, Jeongseon and Taebaek.

Meanwhile, 1.41 million bottles of water have been stockpiled for vulnerable groups such as senior citizens. Of those, 283,433 bottles have already been distributed to schools and welfare facilities, with plans to expand the distribution to the general public further.

Gangneung's drought marks the first time a state of national disaster has been declared due to a natural disaster. Until now, such declarations were limited to social disasters, such as the Goseong wildfire in 2019 and the Uljin-Samcheok forest fire in 2022.

Outlook remains grim

Despite recent government measures, what Gangneung urgently needs for drought relief is heavy rain. Yet the outlook remains bleak, with no rain forecast for the next 10 days.

While much of the country saw heavy downpours of 80 to 100 millimeters through Tuesday, Gangneung recorded less than 5 mm ? far below what is needed to ease the city's drought. According to Korea Meteorological Administration records, the city received just over 400 mm of rainfall over the past six months, only 40 percent of the long-term average. If conditions persist, officials warn the Obong Reservoir could run dry by the end of September.

With no significant rain forecast through early September, authorities are scrambling to identify backup supplies, including tapping nearby rivers and exploring the use of Pyeongchang's Doam Dam, which holds 30 million tons of water. However, concerns regarding its water quality as well as long-running disputes over interregional use have delayed its adoption.

AFP News

August 21st, 2025 ( International Business Times News - Delivered by Newstex )

Wildfires have so far ravaged more than one million hectares (2.5 million acres) in the European Union in 2025, a record since statistics began in 2006, according to an AFP analysis of official data.

Surpassing the annual record of 988,524 hectares burnt in 2017, the figure reached 1,015,731 hectares by midday Thursday, representing an area larger than Cyprus.

This calculation is based on a total compiled by AFP from estimates by country from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), at a time when Spain and Portugal are still battling wildfires.

Four countries in the European Union -- Spain, Cyprus, Germany, and Slovakia -- have already experienced their worst year in two decades of existing data.

Spain is struggling with numerous fires in the west of the country, which have claimed four lives. By far the most affected EU country by fires, with more than 400,000 hectares burnt, Spain accounts for nearly 40 percent of the EU total.

Portugal, which holds the unenviable EU record of 563,530 hectares burnt in 2017, is the second-most affected EU country. As of August 21, it has never had an area of this size (nearly 274,000 hectares) burnt so early in the year.

Romania follows with 126,000 hectares while in France 35,600 hectares of forest have been reduced to ashes, mostly in the southern Aude region, which was ravaged by a massive fire in early August.

These calculations by EFFIS, a component of the European climate monitor Copernicus, only take into account fires that have burnt areas of at least 30 hectares.

Outside the EU, Britain is also experiencing a record year, following fires in April during an early heatwave, as well as in northern Scotland at the end of June.

In the Balkans, Serbia is also recording its worst year since statistics began.

By August 19, forest fires in 22 of the 27 EU countries had already emitted 35 megatons of CO2 since January, an unprecedented amount at this point in the year according to EFFIS, indicating the annual record set in 2017 of 41 megatons could be surpassed.

During the previous record year, in 2017, wildfires had killed more than 200 people in the EU, notably in Portugal, Italy, Spain and France.

In 2025, the provisional EU death toll due to fires is 10, according to an AFP count: two people dead in Cyprus, one in France, and seven in the Iberian Peninsula.

urn:contentItem:6GKV-9VM3-RXXX-80RT-00000-00Spain reduces active fires and sees 48-hour window of opportunity to end the blaze2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisSpain reduces active fires and sees 48-hour window of opportunity to end the blaze


Madrid - The situation of forest fires in SpainimprovedthisWednesday with 13 active outbreaks in Operational Situation 2, two less than yesterday, and the good weather conditions offer a "window of opportunity of 48 hours" decisive to put an end to the fires, although there is still alert for strong winds.


This was reported today by the director of Civil Protection and Emergencies, Virginia Barcones, during the daily meeting of the State Coordination Committee (Cecod), in which she took the opportunity to point out that a total of 35 thousand 656 people were evacuated to date because of the fires.
The latest data offered this morning by Cecod showed that there are fourteenactivefires, thirteen in Operational Situation 2, the highest, and one in level 1, in the regions of Castilla y León (center-north), Galicia (northwest) and Asturias (north).
The King and Queen of Spain began today their tour of some of the places most affected by the fires, where they hope to know first hand the situation of the citizens who suffered the effect of the flames.
For its part, the State Meteorological Agency (Aemet) warned that the danger of forest fires remains at "very high or extreme" levels in large areas of the west and south of the Peninsula, although a drop in temperatures accompanied by an increase in relative humidity in the areas affected by the fire is expected.
The current wave of fires, which began on August 8, raised the number of hectares burned in Spain since the beginning of the year to 413,841 in a total of 272 fires, according to data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS). Regions affected
Galicia maintains an active fire in the provinces of Ourense and Lugo, which caused the closure of several roads since Tuesday due to the danger of the flames.
In Asturias, a "favorable evolution" was evidenced in the threeactiveoutbreaks, although the wind generated a lot of virulence and enhanced the expansion of the burned area.
Several residents of small towns in this region continue tobe evacuated due to the fire which spread very quickly yesterday and which, with the help of firebreaks and existing forest tracks, could be anchored in many parts during the night.
In the case of Castilla y León, the most affected Spanish region, the evolution is also favorable in the nine active fires, so that several evacuated localities now passed to "urban confinement".
The improvement in the weather conditions allowed to contain some fires in "especially complex" areas, where the teams are still working to close the perimeter and attack the fire definitively.
The director of Civil Protection assured today that the aerial means mobilized since August 10 to fight the flames marked between 260 and 280 flight hours per day, with some peaks of 300 hours, a figure not recorded before.

AFP News

August 27th, 2025 ( International Business Times News - Delivered by Newstex )

Wildfires that have swept across Spain this summer are piling pressure on Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez, who is already reeling from a string of corruption allegations against members of his inner circle.

The twin crises have intensified disputes between Sanchez's Socialist minority government and the conservative Popular Party (PP), which governs many of the regions hardest hit by the fires.

Blazes have destroyed more than 415,000 hectares, mostly in August, according to the European Forest Fire Information System, marking a new annual record since reporting began in 2006.

Four people have died and thousands have been evacuated because of this month's fires.

The Socialists blame the PP for failing to implement effective fire prevention policies and for playing down climate change.

The PP points to arson as the cause of the fires and accuses the central government of withholding resources, including enough military support.

PP leader Alberto Nunez Feijoo has proposed creating a creating a national registry of arsonists.

But government minister Angel Victor Torres insisted on public television on Wednesday that regional governments were responsible for disaster response.

"The opposition leader shows up and points fingers instead of helping," he said, referring to the proposed arson registry.

Defence Minister Margarita Robles said many PP-led regional governments had "failed to act".

"When there has been no investment in prevention, it is not enough to say, 'The army will arrive,'" she told radio station Ser.

PP spokeswoman Ester Munoz countered, accusing the government of scapegoating.

"The response of a "serious government should be 'where and when do you need resources' and not that local authorities are incompetent," she said.

The political debate mirrors the controversy that followed deadly floods in October 2024 in PP-governed Valencia.

The row comes as Sanchez's political standing has taken a hit from several investigations into alleged corruption among his inner circle.

His wife, Begona Gomez, has been ordered to appear in court again in September for questioning into alleged embezzlement of public funds.

Sanchez has dismissed the allegations against his wife -- which are related to her past job at Madrid's Complutense University -- as an attempt by the right to undermine his government.

The prime minister's former right-hand man, Santos Cerdan, was detained in June in an ongoing probe into alleged kickbacks for public contracts.

And his younger brother, David Sanchez, has been under investigation since 2024 for alleged embezzlement, influence peddling and tax fraud.

Sanchez's minority government is propped up by smaller regional parties and it has struggled to pass legislation or even a budget.

Feijoo has dismissed Sanchez as a "zombie" head of government because of his difficulty in passing laws and called for an early general election.

urn:contentItem:6GKV-9VM3-RXXX-81WW-00000-00Forest fires are still affecting areas of Zamora, León, Lugo and Ourense.2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisForest fires are still affecting areas of Zamora, León, Lugo and Ourense.


The new monster of the forest fire is feeding back on itself, to take on a greater dimension and at times overtake the extinguishing teams, which only when there are no extreme weather conditions so frequent in recent weeks in the western interior of the Iberian Peninsula can dominate it. This was confirmed yesterday, as have so many other firefighters and specialists throughout this August, Antonio Fernandez, director of the device to combat the flames of one of the foci that is proving more difficult to dominate, the Porto de Zamora, which punished the region of Sanabria and also affects part of Leon. In these two provinces and the Galician provinces of Lugo and Ourense there were still several uncontrolled fires yesterday, eighteen days after the beginning of the crisis, now much less virulent, but not over.


The new drop in temperatures forecast for today in the burned Spain should allow a new advance in combating the flames, as happened last week, and while still waiting for the intervention of the best and most infallible firefighter, the rain. According to the State Meteorological Agency, Aemet, only from tomorrow there could be precipitations, although little copious, in the affected areas, specifically in the case of Galicia and north of León. Meteogalicia, an agency under the Xunta, has predicted that water will fall during the afternoon and, especially, tonight in the areas devastated by the fire in Ourense.
Two soldiers were seriously injured in Trasmiras by a collision of their vehicle with a cattle truck.
In this province two soldiers were injured yesterday at noon on the Rías Baixas Highway, at the height of Trasmiras, about 50 kilometers from Ourense in the direction of Zamora, when the vehicle in which they were traveling collided with a cattle truck.
Also in Ourense there was yesterday the news that the Xunta lifted the situation two of forest alert that ruled throughout the province for 14 days, in which has burned more than 10% of the surface. In Castilla y León five level two fires were still out of control yesterday, the one in Porto de Zamora and the ones in La Baña, Colinas del Campo, Garaño and Fasgar, the latter started 18 days ago. In Galicia there was one in that situation, that of A Pobra do Brollón, in Lugo, which spread to the neighboring municipality of Quiroga, one of the most affected in recent weeks by the giant fire of more than 30,000 hectares, which devastated the region of Valdeorras, in the province of Orense. In Quiroga, as has also happened in recent days in the region of Sanabria, the neighbors felt the dismay of seeing the flames that they thought they had overcome and were in the position of suffering the fire on the fire.

urn:contentItem:6GPP-BCN3-RT3X-8047-00000-00‘Biggest’ Cruise-In went smoothly, says president2025-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 32-33‘Biggest’ Cruise-In went smoothly, says presidentDan Ferguson

As Jason Molden was driving his ‘72 Monte Carlo from his home in Strathcona County, Alta., to Aldergrove, he found out there was a forest fire in his way.

“Fortunately I got a tip from a friend saying, ‘hey, the road was closed’,” Molden recounted.

“I diverted around. I think (the new route) went down Highway 24. What a gorgeous highway that was.”

It was Saturday, the day of the Langley Good Times Cruise-In, and Molden had parked his car on Fraser Highway, with a miniature, custom-made slot car track running laps in his engine compartment.

Molden’s was one of about 1,300 vehicles on display at Canada’s largest charity car show.

Cruise-In president Riccardo Sestito said it was the biggest turnout for the annual show since it moved to Aldergrove, and the event went well.

“It was the smoothest one yet,” Sestito commented.

“There were no incidents.” Requiring everyone to pre-register worked out well, Sestito said, and he thinks the practice should continue.

“They came and they had their spots and everything was done. First time we’ve done that, it worked out well, so I think that’s the future.”

Organizers were able to find extra parking along 265A Street, and at the Aldergrove community centre – which had extra space now that the KFC is gone.

An estimated 90,000 to 100,000 spectators turned out for the 26th (28th year) Langley Good Times Cruise-In.

Hundreds of them waited in line at the InN-Out food truck for a taste of the cuisine from the well-regarded, California-based burger chain.

Aldergrove residents Kevin and Misty Busch, who live about five minutes away, were first in line.

“We came bright and early, when the sun wasn’t shining,” said Kevin, who described himself as a die-hard In-N-Out fan.

When Misty had a look early in the morning, she discovered no-one was in the line-up.

“In-N-Out Burger is a great company that donates 100 per cent of their proceeds to this charity (Cruise-In)” Kevin noted. “(They have a) great history, family-run business. We’re huge fans. Been to many locations across the U.S.”

By the time the truck was getting ready to start serving, hundreds had lined up behind the couple.

Luis Hernandez, In-N-Out manager of special foreign events, described it as “our annual cookout event,” the only Canadian destination for the chain’s community food truck. “We’ve been doing it for many years and there are loyal customers in front of me who have been waiting since 1 a.m., so we’re super grateful for that.”

One of the biggest car clubs at the event, the B.C.Hot Rod Association, arrived with 70 cars, plus T-shirts and caps to sell.

BCHRA director of membership Walter Wagner said they arrived about 6 a.m.

“We love to come here,” Wagner said. “It’s gonna be a great day and we get new members here.”

Established in 1957, he said the club has 456 active members located in B.C, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Washington, Oregon and California.

Jodi Steeves, with the Aldergrove Business Association, who went with a 1950’s diner look for the ABA booth, said the annual show is, by and large, a boon to the local business community.

“It does bring a lot of money to the community,” Steeves remarked.

“I know some business do get hurt a little bit by having to be closed or Fraser Highway being closed, but a lot of business do very well.”

Jim McGregor, who wasn’t sure exactly how many years he’s been emcee on the main stage, was explaining the timeless appeal of Elvis Eite, Steve Elliott, who did three shows.

“He draws a good crowd every time he sings,” McGregor commented. “And nobody ever gets tired of the old classic Elvis music.”

Through the years, the all-volunteer car show has collected nearly $2 million for local charities.

In 2024 alone, the Cruise-In society raised $94,000.

Jodi Steeves, of the Aldergrove Business Association, who went with a 1950’s diner look for the ABA booth, said the annual show is, by and large, a boon to the local business community.

“It does bring a lot of money to the community,” Steeves remarked.

“I know some business do get hurt a little bit by having to be closed or Fraser Highway being closed, but a lot of business do very well.”

Jim McGregor, who wasn’t sure exactlyhowmanyyearshe’sbeenemcee on the main stage, was explaining the timeless appeal of Elvis Eite, Steve Elliott, who did three shows.

“He draws a good crowd every time he sings,” McGregor commented. “And nobody ever gets tired of the old classic Elvis music.”

Through the years, the all-volunteer car show has collected nearly $2 million for local charities.

In 2024 alone, the Cruise-In society raised $94,000.

urn:contentItem:6GPX-0FP3-RS3M-812Y-00000-00LIGHTNING TO SPARK MORE WILDFIRES IN WESTERN US IN COMING DECADES2025-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisLIGHTNING TO SPARK MORE WILDFIRES IN WESTERN US IN COMING DECADES

Washington, D.C: American Geophysical Union has issued the following press release:

Lightning will ignite more wildfires in the western United States in the coming decades as temperatures increase due to climate change, according to a new study that combined predictions for fire-friendly and lightning-friendly weather conditions.

In the western United States, lightning is responsible for more than two-thirds of the area burned by wildfires, and that number is only going to grow. Starting as early as 2031-2060, the study found essentially all of the western United States, or 98%, will see an increase in days posing a risk for lightning – started wildfires.

Areas that are already at high risk for wildfires started by lightning, such as Oregon, Idaho and Montana, are expected to see the largest increase in overall lightning days, with up to 12 more days per summer by 2060. Some areas, particularly in the U.S Southwest, like Arizona, are expected to see a smaller increase as they will simply see less lightning.

The new study was published in Earth ’ s Future, AGU ’ s journal for interdisciplinary research on the past, present and future of our planet and its inhabitants.

“The first step was to project lightning,” said Dmitri Kalashnikov, research scientist at the University of California Merced and lead author on the study. “The typical climate models don ’ t directly simulate lightning. It ’ s too small a process. ”

To get around this, Kalashnikov created his own machine-learning models that predict lightning based on the occurrence of weather variables that are typically found in climate models, such as the amount of moisture in the atmosphere. He published the models last year in AGU ’ s Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres.

He combined his lightning models with the Fire Weather Index projections to predict the number of future days when conditions that encourage lightning and fire ignition and spread coincide.

The Canadian Forest Fire Weather Index, created in 1968, measures how favorable the weather is on a given day for wildfires. It keeps track of temperature, precipitation, humidity and other factors that could impact fires. For example, higher temperatures or lower precipitation, especially prolonged, can increase the chances of a fire.

While there have been previous models created for worldwide changes in lightning, Kalashnikov and his team created models that were specifically trained for locations in the western United States and for a closer timeframe. Their models focused on the years 2030 to 2060, compared to previous models that typically only looked at the end of the century.

Using the Fire Weather Index, researchers were able to predict how the number of days that have a high risk of wildfires will change over the coming decades.

The modeling found the northwestern United States was expected to see the largest increase in lightning days. Parts of Idaho, Oregon and Montana saw the largest increase in this cloud-to-ground lightning, or lightning that strikes the ground, which can ignite flammable vegetation. However, due to lesser increases in the Fire Weather Index, these areas will see slower increases in fire risk compared to areas farther south.

The southern half of the western United States still saw an increase in potential fires started by lightning, despite seeing a lower risk for lightning increases than the northern states. The increase is still projected because the entire West saw a general increase in high-risk days for wildfires as temperatures climb and the risk of droughts and heatwaves increase. In the south, Colorado, Wyoming, Arizona and New Mexico projected the largest increases in wildfires started by lightning.

Kalashnikov said next steps could expand what the models include, like bringing in rainfall amounts to differentiate between dry lightning and wet lightning, or lightning that happens with or without rain. This could help differentiate between thunderstorms that pose a risk of wildfires versus heavy-rain producing storms that could create flash flooding.

“You can ’ t help but wonder what the future will look like, especially if you dig in and you realize that there ’ s actually a lot that we don ’ t understand,” Kalashnikov said.

urn:contentItem:6GK8-4PJ3-S06C-B1KC-00000-00Spain: Spain reports nearly 400,000 hectares burned and 37 arrests due to fires2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisGENERAL NEWSSpain: Spain reports nearly 400,000 hectares burned and 37 arrests due to fires

The humid weather and rainfall have provided some relief to Spanish authorities in their fight against the fires that have been ravaging much of the country for weeks, at a time when more than 391,000 hectares have already been burned so far this year, according to data from the European Forest Fire Information System.

Although 40 fires are still active across the country, recent rain, especially in the province of Le\xF3n, could help firefighters control the situation there, allowing authorities to focus their efforts on other areas.

On Wednesday, the president of the Castile and Le\xF3n region, Alfonso Fern\xE1ndez Mańueco, said that firefighting efforts are progressing favourably thanks to improved weather conditions.

Mańueco also presented an aid plan for those affected, which includes 500 in aid for those who have had to evacuate their homes and up to 185,000 for those who have lost their homes to the flames.

The situation in Castile and Le\xF3n is progressing "significantly" and favourably, as indicated by the president of the autonomous community, partly thanks to the change in weather conditions, which have improved significantly.

"Conditions are favourable and significant progress is being made in extinguishing the fire," Mańueco reported, emphasising that "when circumstances allow, the operation works effectively."

Fires in Galicia have ravaged small, sparsely populated towns, forcing locals in many cases to step in before firefighters arrive.

Firefighting units from Germany arrived in northern Spain on Tuesday to help fight the blazes, Spain's Interior Ministry announced. More than 20 vehicles were deployed to help fight an ongoing blaze in Jarilla in the Extremadura region that borders Portugal, the ministry said.

In Galicia, land management has also played a role. Large stretches of unmanaged vegetation and depopulated villages in forested land have led to the buildup of wildfire fuel, said Adrian Regos, an ecologist at the Biological Mission of Galicia, a research institute.

Air quality deteriorated across large parts of Spain over the past week as a result of the wildfires, data from the EU's Copernicus climate monitoring agency showed. Smoke from the Iberian Peninsula fires reached France, the UK, and Scandinavia, it said.

Several fires have been caused by human activity. Police have detained 37 people for suspected arson and are investigating 89 more, Spain's Civil Guard said Tuesday.

In Portugal, more than 3,700 firefighters were tackling blazes, including four major ones in the north and centre.

Wildfires there have burned about 235,000 hectares, according to EFFIS - nearly five times more than the 2006-2024 average for this period. Two people there have died.

Europe has been warming twice as fast as the global average since the 1980s, according to Copernicus. Scientists say that climate change is exacerbating the frequency and intensity of heat and dryness in parts of Europe, making the region more vulnerable to wildfires.

Source: Euronews

urn:contentItem:6FDD-PV13-RRM4-02V0-00000-00Studies from Indian Institute of Remote Sensing Provide New Data on Photogrammetry Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences (Mapping Forest Fire Dynamics: A Global Perspective on Trends of Severity and Frequency Across Sub-Biomes)2025-03-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:49:02ZLexisNexisSCIENCE - PHOTOGRAMMETRY REMOTE SENSING AND SPATIAL INFORMATION SCIENCESStudies from Indian Institute of Remote Sensing Provide New Data on Photogrammetry Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences (Mapping Forest Fire Dynamics: A Global Perspective on Trends of Severity and Frequency Across Sub-Biomes)


2025 MAR 24 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Science Daily -- Research findings on photogrammetry remote sensing and spatial information sciences are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting out of Dehradun, India, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Understanding forest fire dynamics at a global scale is crucial for effective management & mitigation strategies. This study presents a comprehensive analysis of forest fire trends for severity & frequency across sub-biomes globally, utilizing daily MODIS active fire data (2001-2023)."


The news editors obtained a quote from the research from Indian Institute of Remote Sensing: "The analysis integrates Mann-Kendall trend tests, Sen's slope estimations, & spatial mapping to elucidate the patterns of forest fire occurrences & their implications for different ecosystems. The Mann-Kendall trend analysis identified significant trends in fire severity across sub-biomes. Notable increasing trends were observed in the Tundras of tropical mountains in cryoro belt (1c), Lowland boreal Taiga (2a), Forests & shrublands of temperate oro belt (2b), & Forest-steppe (6a). Conversely, decreasing trends were detected in Tropical pluviseasonal forests & woodlands (8b) & Tropical rainforests (9a). Additionally, spatial assessment of forest fire frequency for the year 2023 provides a detailed visual representation of recent forest fire hotspots across the globe, highlighting regions with the highest fire frequencies. Notable hotspots include Tropical rainforests (9a), Tropical xeric shrublands & woodlands (8a), & parts of the African & South American continents, where fire activity was particularly intense. These regions, marked by high fire density, underscore the urgent need for targeted fire management strategies to mitigate impact of recurrent fires."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The combined analysis of trends for severity, & frequency of forest fires offers valuable insights into the evolving fire regimes across global sub-biomes. The findings highlight the impacts of forest fires on biodiversity, carbon cycling, and ecosystem services, guiding more resilient strategies for global environmental changes."
For more information on this research see: Mapping Forest Fire Dynamics: A Global Perspective on Trends of Severity and Frequency Across Sub-Biomes. The International Archives of the Photogrammetry, Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences, 2025,XLVIII-M-5-2024():117-123. (The International Archives of the Photogrammetry, Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences - http://www.isprs.org/publications/archives.aspx). The publisher for The International Archives of the Photogrammetry, Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences is Copernicus Publications.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.5194/isprs-archives-XLVIII-M-5-2024-117-2025.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting S. Mamgain, Indian Institute of Remote Sensing, Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO), Department of Space, 4, Kalidas Road, Dehradun 248001, India. Additional authors for this research include B. Ghale, A. Roy, H. C. Karnatak.
Keywords for this news article include: Indian Institute of Remote Sensing, Dehradun, India, Asia, Photogrammetry Remote Sensing and Spatial Information Sciences, Science.
